If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to gross negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty of 15 percent of the amount of such deficiency shall be added thereto in addition to the 15 percent prescribed by subsection (a). (d) Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any provision of this chapter or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the deficiency shall be added thereto in addition to the 15 percent prescribed by subsection (a). (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-91. - Administration and enforcement authority; recordkeeping; confidentiality of reports. (a) Authority of the license department. The license department shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this article. (b) Rules and regulations. The license department shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other laws of the city and the state, or the constitution of the state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the taxes hereunder. (c) Records required from licensee; form. Every licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the license department may require. (d) Authority to require reports; contents. In the administration of the provisions of this article, the license department may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such people or persons' possession or custody information relating to sales of alcoholic beverages which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the license department and shall set forth the price charged for each sale, the date or dates of sales and such other information as the license department may require. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-92. - Examination of records; audits. The license department or any person authorized in writing by the city may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the licensee, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. In the event a city audit discloses a deficiency of more than three percent over what has been returned and remitted, the licensee shall reimburse the city for all costs of the audit, including but not limited to accountant's fees and out-of-pocket expenses, the value of time expended by city employees in the investigation, including reasonable cost of overhead, and all attorneys' fees and costs of collection if action must be instituted by the city. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-93. - Violations; penalty. Any person found guilty of or entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the offense of failing to pay the tax due, either in whole or in part, shall, upon conviction thereof, be assessed a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 for each such offense. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which any portion of the amount due remains unpaid. Any person found guilty of or entering a plea to violating any other provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in section 6-191. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Secs. 6-94—6-109. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - OPERATING REGULATIONS
Sec. 6-110. - Commencement of business; time limit. All licensees must, within a six-month period after issuance of a license, open for business the establishment referred to in the license and begin the sale of the product or products authorized by the license. Failure to open the establishment and begin the sale as referred to above within the above-prescribed periods shall serve as automatic forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license, and no refund of license fees shall be made to the licensee. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-111. - Discontinuation of business; license forfeiture. Any licensee who shall begin the operation of the business and sale of the product or products as authorized in a license, but who shall, for a period of 180 consecutive days thereafter, cease to operate the business and sale of the product or products authorized by the license, shall upon completion of the 180-day period automatically forfeit its license, and no refund of license fees shall be made to the licensee. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-112. - Sale hours; election day sales. (a) Package sales of alcoholic beverages shall be prohibited between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday. Notwithstanding, the aforementioned hours set forth herein, package sales of alcoholic beverages shall be prohibited on Christmas Day. (b) Except as provided herein, retail consumption dealers shall be prohibited from engaging in the sale of alcoholic beverages between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday, 12:00 midnight and 12:30 p.m. on Sunday. Retail consumption dealers are prohibited from engaging in the sale of alcoholic beverages on Christmas Day. (c) Each retail consumption dealer shall remove from its service area within normal access to the public, members and guests, any and all cans, bottles, glasses, mugs, pitchers, cups or other containers for alcoholic beverages on its premises after 12:30 a.m. on any day. (d) On the day of any state, federal, or local election, no person shall knowingly or intentionally sell or offer to sell any alcoholic beverage at any place within 250 feet of any polling place or the outer edge of any building within which such polling place is established on primary or election day. (e) The hours of operation for wholesalers operating within the city shall be from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. (f) Sunday sales. (1) Sunday sales of distilled spirits or alcoholic beverages for beverage purposes by the drink between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. shall be allowed effective December 11, 2011. (2) Retail sales of malt beverages and wine on Sunday between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. shall be allowed effective December 11, 2011. (3) Retail sales of packaged distilled spirits on Sunday shall not be permitted. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001; Ord. No. 2011-12-01, 12-6-2011; Ord. No. 2011-12-02, 12-6-2011; Ord. No. 2013-03-01, 3-5-2013; Ord. of 10-4-2016 ) Sec. 6-113. - Alcoholic beverage purchases; license restrictions. (a) Licensees for consumption on the premises may purchase from wholesalers, licensed by the city and/or state, distilled spirits, designated by their license, in one-fifth of a gallon, liter or larger containers unless a particular brand is not packaged in these sizes, and then the licensee may purchase the brand in the nearest size to those specified containers. (b) Licensees for package sales may purchase from wholesalers, licensed by the city and/or state, distilled spirits in pints and half pints, in addition to those sizes specified in subsection (a). (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-114. - Delivery of alcoholic beverages. No deliveries of alcoholic beverages shall be made except on the premises for which such beverages are sold. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-115. - Premises; sanitation requirements. All premises shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with the provisions and regulations governing the condition of premises used for storage and sale of food for human consumption. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-116. - Premises; sign restrictions. No licensee shall use signs or any other visible means of advertising the sale of alcoholic beverages which are readily visible from the outside of the building in which the licensee is located. However, nothing contained in this chapter shall prohibit a licensed wholesaler from placing appropriate markings and advertisements upon vehicles used in its business. Licensees shall not be permitted to circumvent this prohibition of outside advertising of alcoholic beverages by leaving such vehicles parked for an unnecessarily extended period of time in a place where the advertisement will be seen by the general public. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-117. - Invoices. Each licensee shall retain in its place of business, for a period of not less than six months, each invoice relating to alcoholic beverages that it has purchased, and such invoices shall be subject to inspection by any duly authorized representative of the city. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-118. - Disturbances, obscenities prohibited. It is unlawful for any licensee to permit any disturbance of the peace, obscenity or public indecency on its premises. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-119. - Leaving premises without paying prohibited. No person shall leave the premises of the licensee without paying his charges for the sale of alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-120. - Premises; interior visibility requirements. No screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing which shall prevent a clear view into the interior shall be permitted in the window or upon the doors of any retail dealer's store; and no booth, screen, partition or other obstruction shall be permitted within the interior of any such store. Each such retail store shall be so lighted that the interior of the store is visible day and night. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-121. - Signs and notices on purchase and consumption restrictions. (a) The licensee shall post in a conspicuous place where the actual transaction takes place within the licensed premises a sign stating that no alcoholic beverages shall be sold to or purchased by any person under 21 years of age and that it shall be unlawful for any person under 21 years of age to falsely misrepresent his age in any manner whatsoever to a licensee. Such sign shall be printed in uniform letters not less than one inch in height. (b) The retail dealer licensee shall display at all entrances or exists to the licensed premises a sign which shall state that it is unlawful to consume any alcoholic beverages or to open any container of alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises or any parking area adjacent thereto. Further, such sign or signs which are necessary shall also be placed in such a manner as to be visible from any parking area adjacent to the licensed premises. (c) It shall be unlawful for any retail dealer to permit, allow or acquiesce in the consumption of any alcoholic beverages or the opening of any container of alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises or any parking area adjacent thereto. (d) All signs required by this section shall be clearly visible and lettering shall be dark and clear. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-122. - Alcoholic beverages with broken seals prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to carry into or have in his possession on those premises any alcoholic beverages in the original package, the seal of which has been broken or the original package opened; provided that the licensee, his manager or agent in charge of the premises may carry damaged or spoiled containers to a secure storage area pending pickup by the wholesaler. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-123. - Underage persons; unlawful activities. It is unlawful for any person under 21 years of age to purchase alcoholic beverages or to intentionally misrepresent his age in the sale of any alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-124. - Sales outside business prohibited; exception. It is unlawful for any sales to be made outside of the place of business licensed for such sale except as otherwise permitted in this chapter. The use of drive-in windows by retail package dealers is permitted. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001; Ord. of 10-4-2016 ) Sec. 6-125. - Employment of certain persons prohibited. (a) It is unlawful in any premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages to employ any person in any capacity whatsoever, including performers, entertainers and musicians, who have been convicted of, or pled guilty or nolo contendere to, or been adjudicated as guilty or liable or entered a first offender plea, within the past ten years, in this or any other state or the United States, to any felony, misdemeanor or violations of regulations of the State of Georgia or other state involving gambling, possession or sale of controlled substances, or the manufacture, distribution, sale, handling, dealing in or possession of alcoholic beverages. In those instances involving corporations, this prohibition shall also apply to the corporation's president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer and all stockholders owning ten percent or more of the corporation's stock. In those instances involving LLCs, this prohibition shall also apply to any member. (b) No licensee shall allow or require a person in his employment under 18 years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or take orders for any alcoholic beverages. This section shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries, or drugstores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-126. - Bottles; misrepresentation of contents. It is illegal for the licensee hereunder to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any other manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-127. - Copy of regulations maintained on premises. It is the duty of the management of the premises licensed hereunder to maintain a copy of this chapter on such premises and to instruct each and every employee of the terms thereof. Each person employed by a licensee under this chapter shall be required at the time of employment to sign a statement verifying that the employee has read the regulations governing the use and sale of alcoholic beverages and understands and will comply with same. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-128. - Verification of age. (a) It is a violation of this chapter for any agent, officer or employee of a licensee to fail to properly check the identification of any patron, member or guest, when selling or otherwise providing any alcoholic beverages, which failure results in an underage person being sold or served, or to have in his possession, while on the licensee's premises, any alcoholic beverage. (b) For the purpose of this section, the term "identification" shall mean any document issued by any governmental agency containing a description of the person so identified, such person's photograph and such person's date of birth. As used herein, the term "identification" shall include, without being limited to, a passport, a military identification card, a driver's license, or a state department of driver services identification card, but not a birth certificate. (c) Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided by section 6-191 of this chapter. (d) Notwithstanding any criminal prosecution which may result from a violation of this section, any licensee employing any officer, agent or employee that fails to comply with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, which failure results in an underage person being sold or served, or having in his possession while on the licensee's premises an alcoholic beverage, may have its license revoked. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-129. - Brown-bagging; defined; prohibited. (a) For the purposes of this section: (1) Brown-bagging means the bringing, taking or carrying of any alcoholic beverage into a business lawfully operating within the city, but not licensed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises, provided that bringing an alcoholic beverage into a house, apartment, room or other unit designed for private residential occupancy shall not fall within this definition. (2) Brown-bagging shall include the following prohibited acts: a. Any person who brown-bags; b. Any person participating in consumption of any alcoholic beverage being brown-bagged; c. Any person who consumes an alcoholic beverage on any premises lawfully operating in the city, except for those premises licensed for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages or otherwise exempted from the definition of brown-bagging by virtue of the private residential character of the occupancy; d. Any employee of the business establishment in whose presence brown-bagging knowingly or with reckless indifference occurs; e. Brown-bagging is prohibited within the city. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-130. - Inspections of premises. The business premises of any licensee, including any outbuildings, shall be subject to inspection at any and all reasonable times by representatives of the city police and fire departments. Such inspection would be permitted for the purpose of verifying the licensee's compliance with all city and state regulations relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages. The city shall have the specific right to conduct an audit and/or inventory of any retail licensee for the purpose of determining whether the licensee is maintaining the required amount of inventory. Each licensee shall submit to the city at the initial application and at each yearly renewal proof of its required amount of inventory. Failure to maintain such inventory shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the license subject to the hearing procedures as described in section 6-189. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Secs. 6-131—6-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS FOR RETAIL CONSUMPTION ON PREMISES
Sec. 6-150. - Fire regulations applicable; inspection. Where a minimum sleeping or seating capacity is prescribed, the same shall be judged by reasonable standards. The fire department shall, upon the request of the license department, inspect such premises and report its findings. All premises licensed hereunder shall conform at all times with the fire regulations established by the city. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-151. - Service; on trains and planes. Nothing herein shall prohibit the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on dining or club cars of trains on airplanes in transit on regular schedules. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-152. - Service; by employees only. Drinks hereunder shall only be served by employees of the licensee. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-153. - Service; backrooms; when prohibited. The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption by persons in any back room which is not normally open to the general use of the public, members or guests, is prohibited, except that private parties or conventions which have been scheduled in advance may be served in public or private dining rooms or meeting rooms in restaurants, hotels, motels, private clubs and private recreational clubs, and, provided further, that this prohibition shall not apply to the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption hereunder to the registered guests of any hotel or motel in their designated rooms. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-154. - Pricing, delivery and consumption requirements. (a) Each licensee shall maintain a schedule of the price charged for all alcoholic beverages to be served and consumed on the licensed premises or in any room or part thereof. The licensee shall not vary the schedule of prices from day to day or from hour to hour within a single day. The schedule shall be effective for not less than one calendar week. (b) No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee shall: (1) Offer or deliver any free alcoholic beverage to any person or group of persons; (2) Deliver more than two alcoholic beverages to one person at a time; (3) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons any alcoholic beverage at a price less than the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same calendar week, except at private functions not open to the public; (4) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons an unlimited number of alcoholic beverage during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public; (5) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver alcoholic beverages to any person or group of persons at any one day at prices less than those charged the general public on that day, except at private functions not open to the public; (6) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver alcoholic beverages, including malt beverages, by the pitcher, except to two or more persons at any one time; (7) Increase the volume of alcohol contained in a drink without increasing proportionately the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same calendar week; encourage or permit on the licensed premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize; (8) No licensee shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the licenses premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (b) of this section. (c) No provision of this section shall be construed to prohibit licensees from offering free food or entertainment at any time, provided all patrons, members and guests are allowed equal access to such free food, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe when sold with meals or to more than one person, or to prohibit any hotel or motel from offering room service to registered guests. Otherwise no food and alcoholic beverage package may be offered by any licensee. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-155. - Brewpubs. (a) Brewpubs shall be allowed to operate in the city provided they are licensed by the state and comply with all state statutes, rules and regulations. (b) Brewpubs which sell distilled spirits or wine must obtain retail consumption licenses for such beverages as a precondition to sales of distilled spirits or wine. (c) Malt beverage excise taxes shall be imposed on the licensee for all malt beverages produced by brewpubs. Such licensee shall provide such reports and remit taxes due as by malt beverage wholesalers. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-156. - Private clubs and private recreational clubs. Private clubs and private recreational clubs meeting the standards of this chapter may sell alcoholic beverages at any location on premises under their control and may include multiple points of sale under one license, provided such sales are otherwise lawful under state law. In those instances where state law requires more than one license, a second or subsequent city license shall be obtained and the fee therefor paid as provided in section 6-33. In any event all sales shall be reported for tax purposes and all management and sales personnel shall meet the standards of this chapter. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-157. - Alcoholic beverage caterers. (a) For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: (1) Food caterer means any person who, for consideration, prepares food for consumption off the premises. (2) Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer means any person licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the state and who possesses a license by a local government in the state authorizing such person to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages by the drink off licensed premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. (3) Authorized catered function means an event at a location not otherwise licensed for consumption of alcoholic beverages by the drink at which alcoholic beverages are furnished, for consideration, and sold, dispensed or provided free of charge to persons present at the event, by the drink, pursuant to a permit obtained under this section. a. The hours and days of sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages under this section shall be the same as provided for sale by the drink. b. No licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall employ any person under 18 years of age to dispense, serve, sell or handle alcoholic beverages at authorized catered functions. c. As a condition of permit issuance, alcoholic beverage caterers licensed by jurisdictions other than the city shall be provided a copy of the city's alcoholic beverages ordinances, and shall indicate, by signature, that they have received such ordinances and acknowledge the applicability of such ordinances to their operations. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-158. - Gambling, pinball machines, etc., prohibited on premises. It shall be unlawful for any licensee hereunder to permit gambling, betting, games of chance, punch boards, slot machines, pinball machines, electronic games, lotteries or the operation of any schemes for hazarding money or any other thing of value in the place of business or in any room adjoining the same, owned, leased or controlled by the license holder. However, the preceding sentence does not apply to the Georgia Lottery for Education Act (O.C.G.A. § 50-27-1 et seq.). (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-159. - Sexual conduct definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in sections 6-159 through 6-165, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in these sections, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Licensed premises means any premises in which alcoholic beverages are sold or dispensed for consumption on the premises and shall include any premises which are required by law to be licensed to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. Operator means and includes the owner, license holder, operator, manager, and person in charge of any licensed premises. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-160. - Prohibited acts relating to sexual conduct. (a) No person shall perform on licensed premises acts of or acts which constitute or simulate: (1) Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law; (2) The touching, caressing, or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus, or genitals; or (3) The displaying of any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or the displaying of any portion of any person's pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva, or genitals. (b) No person shall use on licensed premises artificial devices or inanimate objects to perform, stimulate, or depict any of the prohibited conduct or activities described in subsection (a)(1) of this section. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to show, display, or exhibit, on licensed premises, any film, still picture, electronic reproduction, or any other visual reproduction or image of an act or conduct described in subsection (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Cross reference— Sexual conduct upon premises of alcohol consumption dealers, § 8-34. Sec. 6-161. - Solicitation of patrons to purchase drinks. It shall be unlawful for any person employed or working in any capacity in any licensed premises to solicit or encourage patrons to purchase drinks to be consumed by or otherwise disposed of by any such person so employed or working. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-162. - Viewing of prohibited acts through glass partitions. No operator shall knowingly permit any person in the licensed premises to view from the licensed premises, by glass partition or other artifice, an act or conduct described in section 6-160 and performed other than the licensed premises. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-163. - Removal of alcoholic beverages from licensed premises to view prohibited acts. No operator shall knowingly permit any person to remove any alcoholic beverage sold or dispensed on the licensed premises to adjacent or other premises for the purpose of viewing any conduct or activity prohibited on the licensed premises by section 6-160; provided, however, that this section shall not be applicable to a person who removes an alcoholic beverage to his home or place of abode. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-164. - Operator's encouragement of patrons to violate sections. It shall be unlawful for any operator to employ, encourage, permit, or assist any person to engage in any conduct or activity in violation of sections 6-160 through 6-163. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-165. - Suspension and revocation of alcoholic beverage licenses; penalty for violation of chapter. (a) The violation of any provision of this article by the operator of any licensed premises shall constitute grounds for the suspension and revocation of any and all alcoholic beverage licenses issued to such operator. (b) Any person who violates any provision of this article may be issued a citation and, upon conviction in the municipal court, shall be punished as provided in section 6-189. (c) Nothing in this chapter shall prevent a license from being subjected to both criminal prosecution in the municipal court and suspension or revocation proceedings before the city council for the same illegal activity. The standard of proof for a conviction of a criminal offense in the municipal court shall be proof beyond a reasonable doubt. The standard of proof in proceedings concerning suspension or revocation of a license before the city council shall be proof by a preponderance of the evidence. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Secs. 6-166—6-174. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - WHOLESALE LICENSE
Sec. 6-175. - License provisions applicable. All provisions pertaining to application for licenses as described in article II of this chapter shall apply with equal force to wholesale licenses except as modified herein. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-176. - License; state license prerequisite. Any wholesaler in alcoholic beverages who is licensed by the state and maintains a fixed location in the city shall be granted a license to distribute such beverage at wholesale in the city upon application for a license. The application shall be accompanied by the presentation of satisfactory evidence that the wholesaler, or agent of the wholesaler, understands and agrees to comply with the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-177. - License; fee. (a) The license fee for each wholesale dealer shall be $100.00. (b) All license fees shall be paid on or before January 1 of each calendar year or at the time of the granting of an application for a license. (c) All license fees shall be paid in full regardless of when a license is granted. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Secs. 6-178—6-184. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - VIOLATIONS AND REVOCATIONS
Sec. 6-185. - Periodic inspection for compliance. Certified officers of the city police department shall have the authority to inspect establishments licensed hereunder during the hours in which the premises are open for business. The inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-186. - Notice of license department's determinations; service thereof. Service of any notice required to be given by this chapter may be made on any person identified as a licensee in section 6-34. Notice shall be in writing. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail such service shall be addressed to the licensee at its address as it appears in the records of the license department. The burden shall be on the licensee to provide notice, in writing, of any change of address for service of notices and process. In the case of service by mail of any notice required by this article, the service is complete at the time of deposit in the United States Postal Service. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-187. - Licenses; automatic revocation conditions. Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages, the city license to deal in such products, issued pursuant to this chapter, shall thereupon be automatically revoked without any action by the mayor and council or any other city officer being necessary. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-188. - Emergency suspension. (a) The mayor, or his designee, has the authority to suspend a license for a short-term period not to exceed ten days. The mayor's decision shall be in writing, with the term of the suspension and the reasons therefor stated, and shall be mailed or delivered to the licensee. It is not necessary that the mayor consult or obtain the approval of the council prior to said suspension. (b) A short-term suspension by the mayor must be for an emergency cause. (c) "Emergency cause" for the short-term suspension of a license shall consist of a second or subsequent violation by the same licensee on the same premises within a two-year period of any state or federal laws, administrative regulations of the state or city ordinances regulating such business holding a license, including those prohibiting gambling, regulating the sale, manufacture, distribution, handling, dealing in, and possession of alcoholic beverages, including the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages to underage persons in an unlawful manner, and the manufacture, sale, or distribution of any controlled substance which puts the city and the health and safety of its citizens at such a risk that an immediate suspension is necessary until a hearing as provided for in section 6-189 can be held. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-189. - License; suspension and revocation. (a) Except as provided in sections 6-187 and 6-188 no license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued pursuant to this chapter shall be suspended or revoked, except for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing and upon the prior three-day written notice to the holder of the license of the time, place and purpose of the hearing and a statement of the charges upon which the hearing shall be held. (b) "Due cause" for the suspension or revocation or such license shall consist of the violation of any federal or state law, administrative regulation or city ordinances regulating such business (including but not limited to any violation of this chapter), or the violation of any federal or state law, state administrative regulation or city ordinance prohibiting gambling, or regulating the sale, manufacture, distribution, handling, dealing in, and possession of alcoholic beverages, including the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages to underage persons in any unlawful manner, or the violation of any federal or state law, state administrative regulation or city ordinance relating to the manufacture, sale or distribution of any controlled substance. (c) The hearing will be conducted by the mayor and council or by a hearing officer appointed by the mayor. The hearing officer shall be an attorney licensed to practice in the state. (d) At the hearing the licensee shall have the right to represent itself or be represented by counsel, may cross-examine all witnesses offered by the city, and may present evidence in its own behalf. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply to hearings under this section, although the hearing officer shall have the right to exclude evidence which carries no indicia of reliability. All testimony shall be offered under oath or affirmation. Both the city and the licensee shall have the right to subpoena witnesses. (e) For hearings conducted by a hearing officer, the hearing officer shall issue a report to the mayor and council within ten days of the completion of the hearing. The report shall contain the hearing officer's finding(s) and recommendation(s). Such recommendation(s) shall take into consideration the nature of the violation(s), preventive efforts of the licensee, corrective action taken by the licensee, and the licensee's prior history. Such recommendation(s) may include one or more of the following: suspension of the license for no more than 12 months, revocation of the license, imposition of a probationary period not to exceed 12 months, and/or a civil penalty not to exceed $5,000.00. (f) The hearing officer's report shall be transmitted to the mayor and council, along with a complete transcript of the hearing. A hearing will be scheduled before the mayor and council. At that hearing the hearing officer may outline the evidence heard and the basis for his recommendation(s). The licensee or its representative may make a statement to the mayor and council in its behalf. Neither side shall introduce any new evidence. (g) The mayor and council shall determine the penalty or penalties imposed by majority vote of those present and voting. Such penalty may include one or more of the following: suspension for no more than 12 months; probation for no more than 12 months, provided that a licensee currently on probation may have its probation extended for an additional 12 months to begin at the end of the current probationary period; revocation; and/or a civil penalty not to exceed $5,000.00. (h) The decision of the mayor and council shall be in writing, with the reasons therefor stated, and shall be mailed or delivered to the licensee within ten days of the hearing date. (i) A total of three separate and unrelated violations within 24 months, whether or not within the probationary period, shall constitute grounds for permanent revocation. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-190. - No refunds following suspension or revocation. In the event a license issued hereunder is suspended or revoked, the licensee shall not be entitled to a refund of any portion of the application or license fees previously remitted. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001) Sec. 6-191. - Violation; penalty. In addition to the other remedies outlined in this article, any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter (except failure to pay taxes due under article III), or entering of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere thereto, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or six months' imprisonment, or by both a fine and imprisonment. (Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 1-1-2001)

div.head: Chapter 8 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 8-1—8-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 18; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 42.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 8-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adult bookstore means any commercial establishment in which is offered for sale any book or publication, film or other medium, which establishment is distinguished or characterized by such media which depict nudity or sexual conduct. Adult dancing establishment means a business that features dancers displaying or exposing any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or the displaying of any portion of any person's pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva or genitals. Adult movie house means any movie theater which on a regular, continuing basis shows films with any type of "X" rating by the Motion Picture Coding Association of America or any movie theater which presents for public viewing on a regular, continuing basis "adult films" depicting sexual conduct. Adult video store means an establishment having as a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, videotapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to either nudity, or sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual act. Nudity means the showing of the human male or female genitals or pubic area with less than a full, opaque covering or the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. Retail consumption dealer of alcohol means any person who sells alcoholic beverages of any type for consumption on the premises of such dealer. Sexual conduct means acts of masturbation, homosexuality, sodomy, sexual intercourse or physical contact with a person's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks or, if such person is female, breast. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. I, 5-7-1996) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3. Sec. 8-32. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to regulate adult entertainment establishments, including but not limited to adult bookstores, adult movie houses, adult video stores or adult dancing establishments. Such establishments are known to attract persons involved in criminal activity. Such establishments tend to create an atmosphere and environment contrary to the best interests of minors. However, it is recognized that regulation of such businesses cannot be used to prohibit otherwise constitutionally protected forms of expression. The purpose of the policies and procedures contained in this article are to reduce the possibility of criminal activity, to avoid negative impact upon minors and neighborhoods and to provide a method whereby persons interested in conducting constitutionally-protected businesses can seek and obtain a permit to do so from the city government. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. IV(A), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-33. - Location. (a) Pursuant to the authority granted in O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3, and pursuant to the general powers of zoning and land use planning granted to the city council pursuant to the city Charter, adult bookstores, adult movie houses, adult video stores and adult dancing establishments may only be located within areas zoned for commercial or industrial purposes within the city. (b) No adult bookstore, adult movie house, adult video store or adult dancing establishment shall be located at any place, even if zoned commercial or industrial, if such location is: (1) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of real estate which is either zoned for or currently used for residential uses or purposes. (2) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of real estate upon which any church, school, governmental building, library, civic center, public park or playground is located. (3) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of real estate upon which any other adult bookstore, adult movie house, adult video store or adult dancing establishment is currently located. (4) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of real estate upon which is located any business which is currently licensed by the city or any other licensing authority for the purpose of sale of alcoholic beverages to the public, whether such sale is for consumption upon the premises or not. (5) For purposes of this section, distance shall be by air line measurement from the property line, using the closest property lines of the parcels of land involved. The term "parcel of real estate" means any quantity of land capable of being described by location and boundary, designated and used or to be used as a unit. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. II, 5-7-1996) Cross reference— Zoning, ch. 74. Sec. 8-34. - Sexual conduct upon premises of alcohol consumption dealers. Any person or entity holding a retail consumption dealer license for the sale of alcoholic beverages, and any other person, shall be subject to the following rules: (1) No person shall perform on licensed premises acts of or acts which constitute or simulate: a. Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual act which is prohibited by law; b. The touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals; or c. The displaying of any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or the displaying of any portion of any person's pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva or genitals. (2) No person shall use on licensed premises artificial devices or inanimate objects to perform, simulate or depict any of the prohibited conduct or activities described in subsection (1) of this section. (3) It shall be unlawful for any person to show, display or exhibit, on licensed premises, any film, still picture, electronic reproduction, or any other visual reproduction or image of any act or conduct described in subsection (1) or (2) of this section. (4) It shall be unlawful for any person employed or working in any capacity in any licensed premises to solicit or encourage patrons to purchase drinks to be consumed by or otherwise disposed of by any such person so employed or working. (5) No such licensee shall knowingly permit any person in the licensed premises to view from the licensed premises, by glass partition or other artifice, any act or conduct described in subsections (1), (2), (3) and (4) of this section and performed on premises other than the licensed premises. (6) No such licensee shall knowingly permit any person to remove any alcoholic beverage sold or dispensed on the licensed premises to adjacent or other premises for the purpose of viewing any conduct or activity prohibited on the licensed premises by this article; provided, however, that this section shall not be applicable to a person who removes an alcoholic beverage to his home or place of abode. (7) It shall be unlawful for any such licensee to employ, encourage, permit or assist any person to engage in any conduct or activity in violation of this article. (8) The violation of any provision of this article by an alcohol licensee shall constitute grounds for the suspension and revocation of any and all alcoholic beverage licenses issued to such person or entity. (9) Any person who violates any provision of this section may be cited to appear before the municipal court, and, if found guilty, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. III, 5-7-1996) Cross reference— Sexual conduct at premises licensed to sell alcoholic beverages, § 6-160. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-41 et seq. Sec. 8-35. - Rules for operation. (a) The following rules and regulations shall apply to adult dancing establishments: (1) There shall be no advertisement of adult dancing establishments unless and until a valid permit for such establishment has been issued pursuant to this article. (2) Each adult dancing establishment shall maintain written records of all employees, including but not limited to all persons employed as dancers, which shall include the names, addresses, social security numbers and dates of birth. At all times, the permittee must maintain such records at the place of business for a period of at least the last two years after the termination of the employment of any person. (3) No permittee shall employ or contract with any dancer under the age of 18 years. (4) No person under the age of 18 years shall be admitted to an adult dancing establishment, whether employee or patron. (5) All adult dancing establishments shall be closed between 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m. (6) No adult dancing establishment permittee shall serve, sell, distribute or allow the consumption or possession of any alcoholic beverage or controlled substance upon the premises of the permittee at any time. (7) All dancing shall occur on a platform raised at least two feet from the level of the floor. (8) No dancing shall occur within ten feet of any patron. (9) No dancer shall have physical contact with any other person while on the premises of the establishment. This prohibition applies to contact with all persons, including patrons and fellow dancers. (10) No patron shall be allowed to touch any dancer or give any payment or gratuity to any dancer, and no dancer shall solicit any pay or gratuity from any patron. (b) The following rules and regulations shall apply to all adult entertainment establishments, except in those instances where the rules for adult dancing establishments stated in subsection (a) of this section are in conflict, in which case those rules specifically for adult dancing establishments will apply: (1) There shall be no visual display, including but not limited to advertisements, which can be seen from outside of the building, which depict nudity or sexual conduct or use words describing nudity or sexual conduct. (2) No person under the age of 18 years shall be admitted to any adult entertainment establishment. The minimum age for admission to an adult dancing establishment is 18 years. (3) No adult entertainment establishment permittee shall employ or allow upon the premises for any reason any person under the age of 18 years. (4) An adult entertainment establishment permittee shall conspicuously display all permits required by this article upon the premises at a place near the entrance. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. VI(A), (B), 5-7-1996; Ord. No. 96-17A, §§ 1, 2, 9-1-1998) Sec. 8-36. - Unlawful operation declared nuisance. Any adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this article is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The city may, in addition to or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action pursuant to this article, commence legal action for abatement, removal or enjoinment of any such nuisance. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. VI(C), 5-7-1996) Secs. 8-37—8-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 8-61. - Operation without permit unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an adult bookstore, adult movie house, adult video store or adult dancing establishment unless such business shall have a currently valid permit or, if the business has an expired permit, shall have made proper application for renewal within the time required therefor under this article, unless such expired permit was under suspension or permanently or conditionally revoked at the time that it expired. No permit so issued shall condone or make legal any activity thereunder, if such activity is illegal or unlawful under the laws of the state or the United States. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. IV(B), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-62. - Qualifications. No permit provided for by this article shall be issued to or held by: (1) Any applicant who has not paid all required fees and taxes for a business at that location or all property taxes; (2) Any person who has been convicted of, entered a plea of nolo contendere to or had a bond forfeiture in a charge of any felony or any crime involving moral turpitude in any jurisdiction within the state or any other jurisdiction within the past five years; (3) Any corporation, any of whose officers, directors or shareholders holding five percent or more of the outstanding issued shares of capital stock, has been convicted of, entered a plea of nolo contendere to or had a bond forfeiture in a charge of any felony or any crime involving moral turpitude in any jurisdiction within the state or any other jurisdiction within the past five years; (4) Any partnership or other business association, any of whose officers or members holding more than five percent interest therein have been convicted of, entered a plea of nolo contendere to or had a bond forfeiture in a charge of any felony or any crime involving moral turpitude in any jurisdiction within the state or any other jurisdiction within the past five years; (5) Any person employing, assisted by or financed in whole or in part by any person who has been convicted of, entered a plea of nolo contendere to or had a bond forfeiture in a charge of any felony or any crime involving moral turpitude in any jurisdiction within the state or any other jurisdiction within the past five years; or (6) Any applicant who is not qualified to hold a license or conduct business according to the laws of the United States or the state. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. IV(C), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-63. - Application—Contents. (a) Each application for an adult entertainment establishment permit shall contain the following information: (1) The applicant's full, true name and any other name used by the applicant during his entire adult life. (2) The present address and telephone number of the applicant. (3) The previous addresses of the applicant, if any, for a period of five years immediately prior to the date of the application and the dates of residence at each. (4) Acceptable documentary proof that the applicant is at least 18 years of age. (5) The applicant's height, weight, color of eyes and hair and date and place of birth. (6) Two photographs of the applicant, at least two inches by two inches, taken within the last six months. (7) Business, occupation or employment history of the applicant for the five years immediately preceding the date of the application. (8) The business permit history of the applicant, including information relating to previous businesses owned or operated by the applicant in any jurisdiction which required special licenses or permits. Specifically, applicants must disclose full details concerning any license or permit for any adult entertainment business or other licensed or permitted business which was revoked or suspended. Such disclosure must include a full explanation of the reasons for previous revocation or suspension of license or permit. (9) For each applicant, full disclosure is required as to all convictions, pleas of nolo contendere, or bond forfeitures during the entire life of such applicant, exclusive of traffic violations. For each such matter the applicant must give the date, court and jurisdiction, including a detailed description of the nature of the crime. (10) If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the place and date of incorporation, and the names and addresses of each of its current officers and directors, and each stockholder holding more than five percent of the stock in the corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the name, residence address and dates of birth of the partners, including limited partners. If the applicant is a limited partnership, it shall furnish a copy of its certificate of limited partnership exactly as filed in the superior court. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply. The applicant corporation or partnership shall designate one of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated person shall complete and sign all application forms required of an individual applicant under this article, but only one application fee shall be charged. If the applicant is a corporation, partnership or any business association, full particulars as to each officer, director, partner or shareholder holding five percent of the outstanding issued shares of capital stock must be given in response to each of the items in subsections (1) through (9) of this section. (11) The name and address of the owner and lessor of the real property upon which the business is to be conducted, and a copy of the lease or rental agreement. (12) Such other identification and information as the police department may require in order to discover the truth of the matters specified in this section as required to be set forth in the application. (13) The age and date of birth of the applicant, any partners, any and all officers, any stockholders of more than five percent of the shares of the corporation stock outstanding and directors of the applicant if the applicant is a corporation. (14) Whether the applicant, any partners or any of the officers or stockholders holding more than five percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation, or the directors of the applicant if the applicant is a corporation, have ever been convicted of any crime constituting a felony, or any crime not a felony, involving moral turpitude in the past five years, and, if so, a complete description of any such crime, including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction and any disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed or whether terms of disposition have been fully completed. (15) The city shall require the individual applicant to furnish fingerprints of the applicants. (16) If the applicant is a person doing business under a trade name, a copy of the properly recorded trade number. If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of the authority to do business in the state, including articles of incorporation, trade name affidavit, if any, and last annual report, if any. (17) At least three character references from individuals who are in no way related to the applicant or individual shareholders, officers or directors of a corporation and who are not or will not benefit financially in any way from the application if the permit is granted and who have not been convicted of any felony or any other crime involving moral turpitude in the past five years. The city clerk shall prepare forms consistent with the provisions of this subsection for the applicant who shall submit all character references on such forms. (18) The address of the premises to receive the permit. (19) Whether the premises are owned or rented, and if applicant has a right to legal possession of the premises, copy of those documents giving such legal right. (20) A plat by a registered engineer, licensed by the state, showing the location of the proposed premises in relation to the neighborhood, the surrounding zoning, its proximity to any church, school, public park, governmental building or site, alcohol sales business or other business regulated under this article. (b) Each application for an adult entertainment establishment permit shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: (1) If the applicant is an individual, the individual; (2) If a partnership, by the manager or general partner; (3) If a corporation, by the president of the corporation; or (4) If any other organization, or association, by the chief administrative official. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. IV(D), 5-7-1996; Ord. No. 96-17A, § 3, 9-1-1998) Sec. 8-64. - Same—Fees. No application shall be considered filed until payment of all application fees are received by the city clerk. The city council shall establish a schedule of fees, which shall include an administrative fee for each permit sought, an investigatory fee for each individual to be investigated prior to decision by the city council and a permit fee, which shall be the fee set by the city council for the issuance of each permit. If a permit is denied for any reason, the city clerk shall immediately refund the tendered permit fee. The administrative fee and all investigatory fees shall be nonrefundable. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. IV(E), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-65. - Investigation. After the application is filed with the city clerk, there shall be a 30-day period during which the city shall investigate the application and the background of the applicant and all other individuals whose backgrounds are to be investigated pursuant to the requirements of this article. If additional information is required from the applicant, the city clerk shall mail to the applicant, at the address given upon the application, a written request for such additional information as is required, and the 30-day period of investigation shall be tolled from the date of the mailing of the letter of inquiry until the date when all such information is provided to the city clerk in the form requested. Upon completion of the investigation and review of all documents, the city council shall consider whether or not to grant the permit requested. Among those factors to be considered are whether: (1) All required fees have been paid; (2) The application conforms in all respects to the provisions of this article; (3) The applicant has made a material misrepresentation in the application; (4) The applicant and all individuals required to be investigated have fully cooperated in the investigation of the application; (5) The applicant, shareholders, directors, partners or financiers of the proposed business have been convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of a felony or any other offense involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or moral turpitude; (6) The applicant or any other of the individuals involved with the proposed business have ever had an adult entertainment establishment permit or other similar license or permit denied or revoked in this or any other jurisdiction prior to the date of the application; (7) The building, structure, equipment or location of such proposed business would comply with all applicable laws, including but not limited to health, zoning, distance, fire and safety requirements and standards; (8) The applicant and all individuals involved with the proposed business are at least 18 years of age; (9) There will be a responsible person on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open; (10) The granting of such permit will create a violation of this article or any other ordinance of the city or of the county or of any state or federal statute; and (11) Anything about the design, location, hours of operation or any other factor concerning the proposed business would create an unreasonable risk of harm to the health, safety or morals of minors or an unreasonable degradation of an established neighborhood. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. V(A), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-66. - Hearings for initial application or application for renewal. After the investigatory period has ended, the city clerk shall place the issue upon the agenda of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city council, at which time a hearing shall be conducted. Such hearings shall follow the normal administrative procedures, with the mayor or mayor pro tempore acting as chairperson. The applicant will be permitted to appear and make an oral presentation and present documentary evidence and testimony in support of the application. Questions may be addressed to the applicant or any other person who appears before the city council. A decision shall be reached by the city council by the close of business on the next business day following the conclusion of the hearing. A written notice of decision, including the reason for any denial, shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. V(B), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-67. - Renewals. Permits for adult entertainment establishments may be renewed on an annual basis, provided that the permittees continue to meet all of the requirements set out in this article. The city clerk will provide a form for an application for renewal. If any facts have changed since the initial application for the permit, full particulars as to any such change must be given in the same form as an initial application for permit. The renewal fee shall be established by resolution of the city council from time to time. All fees owed to the city, including the renewal fee and any other type of administrative fee, utility bill, fine or any other type indebtedness owed to the city, must be paid before the issuance of a renewal permit. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. V(C), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-68. - Permits nontransferable. No adult entertainment establishment permit may be sold, transferred or assigned by a permittee. This absolute prohibition against transfer applies to voluntary sales, transfers by operation of law, inheritance, automatic transfer to a bankruptcy trustee or other fiduciary or levy by creditors. If the permittee named in the permit issued ceases to do business under that permit in that location for any reason, the permit shall be automatically canceled and thereafter null and void. However, if the permittee is a partnership, and one or more of the partners should die, the surviving partner or partners may acquire, by purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner or partners without affecting a surrender or termination of such permit. In such case, the surviving partner may obtain a renewal of the permit in his own separate name from the city clerk, provided that the surviving partner is not otherwise disqualified from holding the permit. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. V(C), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-69. - Change of location. A permit shall be issued for each physical location of an adult entertainment establishment. After a permit is issued, it shall not be valid for any adult entertainment operated in any other location than that specified on the permit. Therefore, if an applicant wishes to relocate, the entire application procedure shall be recommenced as if no permit had ever been issued. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. V(D), 5-7-1996) Sec. 8-70. - Revocation. The city council retains authority to revoke any permit issued under this article. If the city council believes that there is any failure to maintain any of the qualifications to hold a permit, any variance between the permitted use and the actual use in violation of this article, any material misrepresentation in any application which was not discovered until after the permit was granted, any violation of any provision of this article or any other reason to believe that the continued operation of an adult entertainment establishment is harmful to the health, morals, peace and dignity of the community, then it shall issue to the permittee a notice of hearing. The notice shall include sufficient information for the permittee to prepare its defense and shall notify the permittee of the time and date of the hearing before the city council wherein the issue of revocation of the permit shall be decided. Such hearing shall be no less than ten days following the date that the notice is mailed to the address of the permittee. At the hearing, the permittee will be allowed to present evidence and examine any witness or evidence submitted before the city council. Following the hearing, the city council shall issue its written decision within a reasonable period of time and mail a copy to the permittee. Any adverse decision shall include specific reasons for such decision. The city council may order any of the following: (1) The permit may be continued without alteration; (2) The permit may be modified so as to place reasonable restrictions upon the permittee's conduct of business for a reasonable period of time so as to deter or prevent a repeat of the type of conduct that led to the disciplinary action; or (3) The permit may be revoked, effective immediately. (Ord. No. 96-17, art. VI(D), 5-7-1996) ARTICLE III. - BONA FIDE COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT MACHINES
Sec. 8-71. - Definitions. As used in this article, the term: Bona fide coin operated amusement machine means: (1) Every machine of any kind or character used by the public to provide amusement or entertainment whose operation requires the payment of or insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, ticket, or similar object and the result of whose operation depends in whole or in part upon the skill of the player, whether or not it affords an award to a successful player pursuant to subsections (b) through (g) of O.C.G.A. Section 16-12-35, and which can be legally shipped interstate according to federal law. Examples of bona fide coin operated amusement machines include, but are expressly not limited to, the following: a. Pinball machines; b. Console machines; c. Video machines; d. Crane machines; e. Claw machines; f. Pusher machines; g. Bowling machines; h. Novelty arcade games; i. Foosball or table soccer machines; j. Miniature racetrack, football, or golf machines; k. Target or shooting gallery machines; l. Basketball machines; m. Shuffleboard games; n. Kiddie ride games; o. Skeeball machines; p. Air hockey machines; q. Roll down machines; r. Trivia machines; s. Laser games; t. Simulator games; u. Virtual reality machines; v. Maze games; w. Racing games; x. Coin operated pool tables or coin operated billiard tables as defined in paragraph (3) of O.C.G.A. Section 43-8-1; and y. Any other similar amusement machine which can be legally operated in Georgia. (2) Every machine of any kind or character used by the public to provide music whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, ticket, or similar object such as jukeboxes or other similar types of music machines. The term "bona fide coin operated amusement machine" does not include the following: (1) Coin operated washing machines or dryers; (2) Vending machines which for payment of money dispense products or services; (3) Gas and electric meters; (4) Pay telephones; (5) Pay toilets; (6) Cigarette vending machines; (7) Coin operated scales; (8) Coin operated gumball machines; (9) Coin operated parking meters; (10) Coin operated television sets which provide cable or network programming; (11) Coin operated massage beds; and (12) Machines which are not legally permitted to be operated in Georgia. Business owner or business operator means an owner or operator of a business where one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public. Class A machine means a bona fide coin operated amusement machine that is not a Class B machine and: (a) provides no reward to a successful player: or (b) rewards a successful player with free replays or additional time to play. Class B machine means a bona fide coin operated amusement machine that rewards a successful player with any combination of items listed in subparagraphs (d)(1)(B) and (d)(1)(C) of O.C.G.A. Section 16-12-35. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012) Sec. 8-72. - Limitation on number of Class B machines at one location. It shall be a privilege for the owner or operator of a business location within the city to offer bona fide coin operated amusement machines to the public at the business location. No business owner or business operator shall offer to the public more than nine Class B bona fide coin operated amusement machines that reward the player exclusively with noncash merchandise, prizes, toys, gift certificates, or novelties at the same business location. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012) Sec. 8-73. - Owner/operator's duty to inform employees of prohibitions and penalties of law. It shall be the duty of every owner or operator of a business location that rewards the player exclusively as described in subsection (d) of O.C.G.A. Section 16-12-35 to inform all employees of the prohibitions and penalties set out in subsections (3), (f), and (g) of O.C.G.A. Section 16-12-35. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012) Sec. 8-74. - Duty of owner or possessor of machine to inform owner or operator of business location of prohibitions and penalties of law. It shall be the duty of every owner or possessor of any bona fide coin operated amusement machine that rewards the player exclusively as described in subsection (d) of O.C.G.A. Section 16-12-35 to inform each business owner or business operator of the business location where such machine is located of the prohibitions and penalties set out in subsections (e), (f), and (g) of O.C.G.A. Section 16-12-35. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012) Sec. 8-75. - Suspension or revocation of alcoholic beverage license upon conviction of violation of law or this Code provision pertaining to bona fide coin operated amusement machines. Conviction of a violation of subsections (e), (f), or (g) of O.C.G.A. Section 16-12-35 by and owner, operator, or employee of a business location offering to the public any bona fide coin operated amusement machine for which business location an alcoholic beverage license has been issued to the City of Jackson, pursuant to chapter 6 of this Code, shall be grounds for the suspension, revocation, or refusal to renew such alcoholic beverage license. Any adverse action against a licensee shall be brought in accordance with section 6-190 of this Code. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012) Sec. 8-76. - Duty of owner or operator to file verified monthly report. It shall be the duty of any business owner or business operator offering to the public bona fide coin operated amusement machines at the business location to provide to the mayor, or his designee, a copy of each verified monthly report prepared in accordance with O.C.G.A. Section 48-17-15, the provisions of which are incorporated herein by reference, together with the penalties authorized by subsection (d) of O.C.G.A. Section 48-17-15. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012) Sec. 8-77. - Bona fide coin operated amusement machines to be kept in plain view; duty to post notice, occupation tax certificate, and other licenses and information. The owner or operator of any business location at which bona fide coin operated amusement machines are offered to the public shall place and maintain the machines in plain view in an area of the business location accessible to any person in the business location. It shall be the duty of every owner or operator of a business location which offers to the public one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines to prominently and conspicuously post a notice, in block letters not less than two inches in height, within ten feet of at least one machine, including the following language: "GEORGIA LAW PROHIBITS PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR WINNING A GAME OR GAMES ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR FREE REPLAYS WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; OR AWARDING ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY OF A VALUE EXCEEDING $5.00 FOR A SINGLE PLAY OF THIS MACHINE." In addition thereto, it shall be the further duty of the owner or operator of a business location to conspicuously post within the place of business its occupation tax certificate, any business or regulatory licenses held for the business at that location including alcoholic beverage license, if any, and the name, address and contact information for the owner of any bona fide coin operated amusement machines located upon the premises. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012) Sec. 8-78. - Enforcement and civil penalties. The owner or operator of any business location in violation of this article shall be entitled to at least 30 days written notice setting forth the facts of the violation with sufficient specificity. For a first violation, the owner or operator voluntarily curing the violation(s) shall cause the notice to be reduced to a warning; provided, however, consideration of the violation may be used in furtherance of sanctions for any subsequent violations. The notice shall be served on the business owner or operator by personal service if the person, firm, corporation or other business entity is resident within Butts County, Georgia, otherwise by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address shown on the business' occupation tax certificate, if a non-resident of Butts County, Georgia. A business owner or operator may request a hearing within the 30 days following service of the notice. The hearing shall be conducted by the mayor and council or a hearing officer appointed by the mayor; the hearing officer shall be an attorney licensed in this state who is disinterested in the proceedings. Hearings shall only be as formal as necessary to preserve order and shall be compatible with the principles of justice. The hearing officer shall make his or her final written determination within ten days of the completion of the hearing. If the hearing officer concludes this article has been violated, the mayor may impose a civil penalty not to exceed $500.00 for the first infraction, and a civil penalty not to exceed $1,000.00 for each subsequent infraction. For a third or subsequent infraction, the privilege of offering bona fide coin operated amusement machines at the business location may be revoked or suspended. (Ord. No. 2012-10-01, § 1, 11-6-2012)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 42; horses or other livestock in parades and demonstrations, § 50-37. State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. - Riding horses, mules, ponies or other animals on sidewalks, roadways or rights-of-way; penalty for violation of section. (a) It shall be unlawful to ride horses, mules, ponies and any other animal upon the sidewalks, roadways or rights-of-way in the city. The city may make exceptions to the preceding sentence for permitted parades. (b) Violation of this article shall be punishable, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. of 5-20-1986(2)) State Law reference— Livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq. Sec. 10-2. - Keeping certain animals; penalty for violation of section. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to have or keep, to pasture, or confine within the corporate limits of the city any horses, mules, donkeys, burros, ponies, cows, calves, sheep or goats. (b) It shall also be unlawful for any person to have or keep within the corporate limits of the city any fowl such as chickens, ducks, turkeys, geese, guinea fowl, pea fowl, peacocks, pigeons, doves, quail or any birds of prey. (c) Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be punished, upon conviction, according to section 1-11. (Ord. of 3-20-1978; Res. of 1-16-2007) Sec. 10-3. - Tethering. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog or anyone having a dog in his possession and control to restrain or anchor a dog for an excessive amount of time to a stationary object by means of a tether, chain, cable, rope or cord. Employees of the animal control division maintain the right to interpret and enforce this section. (b) As a secondary means of restraint to proper enclosure, a dog may be attached to a running cable line or trolley system provided that: (1) Only one dog may be attached to each running cable line or trolley system; (2) Tethers and cables attaching the dog to the running cable line or trolley system must be made of a substance which cannot be chewed by the dog and shall not weigh more than five percent of the body weight of the dog tethered; (3) A running cable line or trolley system must have a swivel installed at each end and be attached to a stationary object that cannot be moved by the dog; (4) The running cable line or trolley system must be at least ten feet in length and mounted at least four feet and no more than seven feet above ground level; (5) The length of the tether from the running cable line or trolley system to the dog's collar should allow access to the maximum available exercise and allow the dog free access to food, water and shelter; (6) Be attached to a properly fitted harness or collar not used for the display of a current rabies tag and other identification; and with enough room between the collar and the dog's throat through which two fingers may fit.
