(20) Consumes alcoholic beverages on any public street, sidewalk or any other public property within the corporate limits of the city. Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages or containers with the seal broken shall be prima facie evidence of consumption. (21) Consumes alcoholic beverages, whether in a vehicle or not, on any public or private parking lot within the corporate limits of the city, except those parking lots maintained at establishments holding a valid license from the city for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages. Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages or containers with the seal broken shall be prima facie evidence of consumption. (Ord. No. 96-26, art. I, 5-21-1996) Sec. 42-163. - Reserved. Sec. 42-164. - Penalty. Any person charged with disorderly conduct shall be arrested and required to post bond prior to his release. Upon conviction of disorderly conduct, the offender shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 96-26, art. III, 5-21-1996) Secs. 42-165—42-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - CRIMINAL TRESPASS AND DAMAGE TO PROPERTY
Sec. 42-181. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish jurisdiction in the municipal court of the city to try criminal trespass and damage to property offenses, to define such offenses and to provide for penalties. (Ord. No. 96-29, 5-21-1996) Sec. 42-182. - Criminal trespass. A person commits the offense of criminal trespass when he does either of the following: (1) Intentionally damages any property of another without his consent; (2) Knowingly and maliciously interferes with the possession or use of the property of another person without his consent; or (3) Commits any of the following acts concerning the premises or property of another: a. Enters upon the land or premises of another person or into any part of any vehicle, railroad car, aircraft or watercraft of another person for an unlawful purpose; b. Enters upon the land or premises of another person or into any part of any vehicle, railroad car, aircraft or watercraft of another person after receiving, prior to such entry, notice from the owner, rightful occupant or, upon proper identification, an authorized representative of the owner or rightful occupant that such entry is forbidden; or c. Remains upon the land or premises of another person after receiving notice from the owner, rightful occupant or, upon proper identification, an authorized representative of the owner or rightful occupant to depart. (Ord. No. 96-29, art. I(A), 5-21-1996) Sec. 42-183. - Criminal damage to property. A person commits the offense of criminal damage to property when he: (1) Knowingly and without authority interferes with any property in a manner so as to endanger human life; (2) Knowingly and without authority and by force or violence interferes with the operation of any system of public communication, public transportation, sewerage, drainage, water supply, gas, power or other public utility service or with any constituent property thereof; (3) Recklessly or intentionally, by means of fire or explosive, damages the property of another person; or (4) With intent to damage, starts a fire on the land of another without his consent. (Ord. No. 96-29, art. I(B), 5-21-1996) Sec. 42-184. - Interference with city property. A person commits the offense of interference with city property when he destroys, damages or defaces property of the city. (Ord. No. 96-29, art. I(C), 5-21-1996) Sec. 42-185. - Injuring, tearing down or destroying mailboxes; injuring, defacing or destroying mail. It shall be unlawful for any person willfully or maliciously to injure, tear down or destroy any mailbox or receptacle intended or used for the receipt or delivery of mail or willfully or maliciously to injure, deface or destroy any mail deposited therein. (Ord. No. 96-29, art. I(D), 5-21-1996) Sec. 42-186. - Penalty. Any person committing any offense under this article of criminal trespass, criminal damage to property, interference with city property or injuring, tearing down or destroying mailboxes or injuring, defacing or destroying mail shall be issued a citation and required to post bond. Upon conviction in the municipal court, the punishment shall be as set forth in section 1-11. Each separate act representing any violation of this article shall be considered a separate offense for the purpose of punishment. (Ord. No. 96-29, art. I(E), 5-21-1996) Secs. 42-187—42-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - PUBLIC INTOXICATION[5]

Sec. 42-201. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish jurisdiction in the city municipal court to try the offense of public intoxication, to define same and to provide for penalties. (Ord. No. 96-32, 6-18-1996) Sec. 42-202. - Determination based on chemical analysis. It shall be unlawful for any person to be drunk or intoxicated upon the public streets, sidewalks and parking lots or at any public place or public meeting within the city. If any person is charged with the offense of public intoxication, he shall submit to chemical analysis of the person's blood, urine, breath or other bodily substance. Upon the trial of the charge of public intoxication, evidence of the amount of alcohol or drug in a person's blood, urine, breath or other bodily substance at the alleged time, as determined by a chemical analysis of the person's blood, urine, breath or other bodily substance, shall be admissible. Where such a chemical test is made, the following provisions shall apply: (1) Chemical analysis of the person's blood, urine, breath or bodily substance, to be considered valid under this article, shall have been performed according to the methods approved by the division of forensic sciences of the state bureau of investigation on a machine which was operated with all its electronic and operating components prescribed by its manufacturer properly attached and in good working order and by an individual possessing a valid permit issued by the division of forensic sciences for this purpose. The division of forensic sciences of the state bureau of investigation shall approve satisfactory techniques or methods to ascertain the qualifications and competence of individuals to conduct analyses and to issue permits, along with requirements for properly operating and maintaining any testing instruments, and to issue certificates certifying that instruments have met those requirements, which certificates and permits shall be subject to termination or revocation at the discretion of the division of forensic sciences. (2) In any criminal trial, the refusal of the defendant to permit a chemical analysis to be made of his blood, breath, urine or other bodily substance at the time of his arrest shall be admissible in evidence against him. (3) When a person shall undergo a chemical test at the request of a law enforcement officer, only a physician, registered nurse, laboratory technician, emergency medical technician or other qualified person may withdraw blood for the purpose of determining the alcohol or drug content therein, provided that this limitation shall not apply to the taking of breath or urine specimens. (4) The person tested may, at his own expense, have a physician or a qualified technician, chemist, registered nurse or other qualified person of his own choosing administer a chemical test in addition to any administered at the direction of a law enforcement officer. The justifiable failure or inability to obtain an additional test shall not preclude the admission of evidence relating to the test taken at the direction of a law enforcement officer. (Ord. No. 96-32, art. I, 6-18-1996) Sec. 42-203. - Acts constituting public intoxication. A person shall be considered drunk or intoxicated when found upon the public streets, sidewalks and parking lots or in any public place or public meeting within the city while: (1) Under the influence of alcohol to the extent that the person creates a danger to himself or others; (2) The person's alcohol concentration is 0.10 grams or more at any time within three hours after his arrest from alcohol consumed before such arrest; or (3) There is any amount of marijuana or a controlled substance, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 16-13-21, present in the person's blood or urine, or both, including the metabolites and the derivatives of each or both without regard to whether or not any alcohol is present in the person's breath or blood. (Ord. No. 96-32, art. II, 6-18-1996) Sec. 42-204. - Probable cause. An officer shall have probable cause to charge a suspect under this article if such person is found in possession of any illegal drugs or paraphernalia commonly associated with drugs of abuse and controlled substances, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-13-21. While possession of such paraphernalia shall not be a separate violation, it shall authorize an officer to request a sample of breath, blood, urine or other bodily substance, in order to determine whether or not the suspect is under the influence of any drugs or alcohol in violation of this article. (Ord. No. 96-32, art. III, 6-18-1996) Sec. 42-205. - Penalty. Any person charged with public drunkenness or intoxication shall be arrested and required to post bond prior to his release. Upon conviction, the offender shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 96-32, art. IV, 6-18-1996) Secs. 42-206—42-230. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - WEAPONS
Sec. 42-231. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Public gathering includes, but shall not be limited to, athletic or sporting events, churches or church functions, political rallies or functions, publicly owned or operated buildings or establishments at which alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises. School safety zone means in, on or within 1,000 feet of any real property owned by or leased to any public or private elementary school, secondary school or school board and used for elementary or secondary education and in, on or within 1,000 feet of the campus of any public or private technical school, vocational school, college, university or institution of postsecondary education. Weapon means and includes any pistol, revolver or any weapon designed or intended to propel a missile of any kind, or any dirk, bowie knife, switchblade knife, ballistic knife or any other knife having a blade of three or more inches, straight-edge razor, spring stick, metal knucks, black jack, any bat, club or other bludgeon-type weapon, or any flailing instrument consisting of two or more rigid parts connected in such a manner as to allow them to swing freely, which may be known as a nunchahka, nunchuck, nunchaku, shurirken or fighting chain, or any disc of whatever configuration, having at least two points or pointed blades which is designed to be thrown or propelled and which may be known as a throwing star or oriental dart or any weapon of like kind, and any stun gun or taser as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-11-106(a). (Ord. No. 96-13, art. I, 5-7-1996) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 42-232. - Carrying at schools and public gatherings. Except as otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to carry to or to possess or have under such person's control while within a school safety zone or at a school building, school function, or school property, or on a bus or other transportation furnished by the school, any weapon or explosive compound. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to carry to or to possess or have under such person's control any weapon or explosive compound while at a public gathering. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. II, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-233. - Exemptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to: (1) Baseball bats, hockey sticks or other sports equipment possessed by competitors for legitimate athletic purposes. (2) Participants in organized sport shooting events or firearm training courses which have been properly permitted in advance by the city council. (3) Persons participating in military training programs conducted by or on behalf of the armed forces of the United States or the state department of defense. (4) Persons participating in law enforcement training conducted by a police academy certified by the Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Council or by a law enforcement agency of the state, or the United States or any political subdivision thereof. (5) The following persons, when acting in the performance of their official duties or when en route to or from their official duties: a. A peace officer as defined by O.C.G.A. § 35-8-2; b. A law enforcement officer of the United States government; c. A prosecuting attorney of this state or of the United States; d. An employee of the state department of corrections or a correctional facility operated by a political subdivision of this state or the United States who is authorized by the head of such correctional agency or facility to carry a firearm; e. A person employed as a campus police officer or school security officer who is authorized to carry a weapon in accordance with O.C.G.A. title 20, chapter 8 (O.C.G.A. § 20-8-1 et seq.), and f. Medical examiners, coroners and their investigators who are employed by the state or any political subdivision thereof. (6) A person who has been authorized in writing by a duly authorized official of the school to have in such person's possession or use as part of any activity being conducted at a school building, school property or school function, a weapon which would otherwise be prohibited by this article. Such authorizations shall specify the weapon which has been authorized and the time period during which the authorization is valid. (7) A person who is licensed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-11-129 or issued a permit pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-38-10, when such person carries or picks up a student at a school building, school function or school property, or on a bus or other transportation furnished by the school or any weapon legally kept within a vehicle in transit through a designated school zone by any person other than a student. (8) A weapon which is in a locked compartment of a motor vehicle or one which is in a locked container in or a locked firearms rack which is on a motor vehicle which is being used by an adult over 18 years of age to bring to or pick up a student at a school building, school function or school property or on a bus or other transportation furnished by the school, or when such vehicle is used to transport someone to an activity being conducted on school property which has been authorized by a duly authorized official of the school; provided, however, that this exception shall not apply to a student attending such school. (9) Persons employed in fulfilling defense contracts with the government of the United States or agencies thereof when possession of the weapon is necessary for the manufacture, transport, installation and testing under the requirements of such contract. (10) The employees of the state board of pardons and paroles when specifically designated and authorized in writing by the members of the state board of pardons and paroles to carry a weapon. (11) The attorney general and those members of his staff whom he specifically authorizes in writing to carry a weapon. (12) Probation supervisors employed by and under the authority of the department of corrections pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 42-8-20 et seq., known as the "State-Wide Probation Act," when specifically designated and authorized in writing by the director of the division of probation. (13) Public safety directors of municipal corporations. (14) State and federal trial and appellate judges. (15) United States attorneys and assistant United States attorneys. (16) Clerks of the superior courts. (17) Teachers and other school personnel who are otherwise authorized to possess or carry weapons, provided that any such weapon is in a locked compartment of a motor vehicle or one which is in a locked container in or a locked firearms rack which is on a motor vehicle. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. III, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-234. - Persons who reside or work within school safety zones. This article shall not prohibit any person who resides or works in a business or is in the ordinary course of transacting lawful business or any person who is a visitor of such resident located within a school safety zone from carrying, possessing or having under such person's control, a weapon within a school safety zone; provided, however, it shall be unlawful for any such person to carry, possess or have under such person's control while at a school building or school function, or on school property, a school bus or other transportation furnished by the school, or at a public gathering, any weapon or explosive compound. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. IV, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-235. - Certain actions not defense to prosecution. It shall be no defense to a prosecution for a violation of this article that: (1) School was or was not in session at the time of the offense; (2) The real property was being used for other purposes besides school purposes at the time of the offense; or (3) The offense took place on a school vehicle. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. V, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-236. - Map as admissible evidence. In a prosecution under this article, a map produced or reproduced by the city for the purpose of depicting the location and boundaries of the area on or within 1,000 feet of the real property of a school board or a private or public elementary or secondary school that is used for school purposes, or within 1,000 feet of any campus of any public or private technical school, vocational school, college, university or institution of postsecondary education, or a true copy of the map, shall, if certified by the city clerk as a true copy, be admissible and shall constitute prima facie evidence of the location and boundaries of the area, provided the city council has approved the map as an official record of the location and boundaries of the area. The prosecutor shall not be precluded from introducing or relying upon any other evidence or testimony to establish any element of this offense, nor from using any map or diagram other than the one which has been approved by the city council. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. VI, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-237. - Discharging firearms. It shall be unlawful for any person, without legal justification, to discharge any firearm within the city limits or at any location where the projectile so discharged could be reasonably expected to enter the geographical or corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. VII, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-238. - Discharging air guns, air pistols or bows. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any air gun or air pistol, or any longbow, crossbow or any other type of bow designed to discharge arrows, in any of the streets or sidewalks of the city or in any of the lots thereof unless permission for the discharge of such devices has been given to the person discharging such device by the owner of the property on which such devices are discharged, and unless the discharging of such device is so controlled that no pellet, shot, arrow or any matter so discharged shall cross the property line of the person granting such permission. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. VIII, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-239. - Offenses involving persons under 18. (a) Notwithstanding any other provision of this article and except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess or have under such person's possessive control a pistol or revolver, whether loaded or unloaded. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally, knowingly or recklessly to sell or furnish a pistol or revolver to any person below the age of 18 years. (c) It shall be lawful for a person under the age of 18 years to possess a pistol or revolver only if such person is: (1) Attending a hunter education course or a firearms safety course; (2) Engaging in practice in the use of a firearm or target shooting at an established range authorized by the governing body of the jurisdiction where such range is located; (3) Engaging in an organized competition involving the use of a firearm or participating in or practicing for a performance by an organized group under 26 USC 501(c)(3) which uses firearms as part of such performance; (4) Hunting or fishing pursuant to a valid license if such person has in his possession such a valid hunting or fishing license if required; is engaged in legal hunting or fishing; has permission of the owner of the land on which the activities are being conducted; and the pistol or revolver, whenever loaded, is carried only in an open and fully exposed manner; or (5) Traveling to or from any activity described in subsections (c)(1) through (4) of this section if the pistol or revolver in such person's possession is not loaded. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally and without legal justification point or aim at another any gun, pistol, or other weapon as defined by this article. For purposes of this offense, it shall be irrelevant whether such firearm pointed at another was loaded or unloaded. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. IX, 5-7-1996) Sec. 42-240. - Concealed weapons. (a) A person commits the offense of carrying a concealed weapon when he knowingly has or carries about his person any weapon or instrument of like character outside of his home or place of business, unless such weapon or instrument of like character is being carried in an open manner and fully exposed to view. (b) This section shall not permit, outside of his home, motor vehicle or place of business, the carrying of a pistol, revolver or concealed firearm by any person unless he has on his person a valid license issued under O.C.G.A. § 16-11-129, and the pistol, revolver or firearm may only be carried in a shoulder or waist belt holster, hipgrip or in any other similar device, handbag, purse, attache case, briefcase or other closed container. Carrying on the person in a concealed manner other than as provided in this section shall not be permitted and shall be a violation of this section. (c) This section shall not forbid the transportation of any firearm by a person who is not among those enumerated as ineligible for a license under O.C.G.A. § 16-11-129, provided the firearm is enclosed in a case, unloaded and separated from its ammunition. This section shall not forbid the transportation of a loaded firearm in any private passenger motor vehicle in an open manner and fully exposed to view or in the glove compartment of the vehicle. (Ord. No. 96-13A, art. III, 6-4-1996) Sec. 42-241. - Penalty. Any person committing any violation of this article may be prosecuted in the municipal court of the city or in any other state or federal court at the discretion of the prosecutor. Any person convicted of any violation of this article in the municipal court of the city shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 96-13, art. X, 5-7-1996; Ord. No. 96-13A, art. IV, 6-4-1996) Secs. 42-242—42-254. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - CIGARETTES AND TOBACCO RELATED OBJECTS—SALE; DISTRIBUTION OR POSSESSION BY MINORS[6]

Sec. 42-255. - Definitions. As used in this article, the term: Cigarettes means any type of tobacco or tobacco product. Community service means a public service which a minor might appropriately be required to perform, as determined by the court, as punishment for certain offenses provided for in this article. Minor means any person who is under the age of 18 years. Proper identification means any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph, or both, and giving such person's date of birth and includes, without being limited to, a passport, military identification card, driver's license, or an identification card authorized under O.C.G.A. §§ 40-5-100—40-5-104. "Proper identification" shall not include a birth certificate. Tobacco related objects means any papers, wrappers, or other products, devices, or substances which are used for the purpose of making cigarettes or tobacco in any form whatsoever. (Ord. No. 98-5, § I, 3-17-1998) Sec. 42-256. - Prohibited acts. (a) (1) It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to: A. Sell or barter, directly or indirectly, any cigarettes or tobacco related objects to a minor; B. Purchase any cigarettes or tobacco related objects for any minor unless the minor for whom the purchase is made is the child of the purchaser; or C. Advise, counsel, or compel any minor to smoke, inhale, chew, or use cigarettes or tobacco related objects. (2) A. The prohibition contained in paragraph (a)(1) of this section shall not apply with respect to sale of cigarettes, tobacco products, or tobacco related objects by a person when such person has been furnished with proper identification showing that the person to whom the cigarettes, tobacco products, or tobacco related objects are sold is 18 years of age or older. B. In any case where a reasonable or prudent person could reasonably be in doubt as to whether or not the person to whom cigarettes or tobacco related objects are to be sold or otherwise furnished is actually 18 years of age or older, it shall be the duty of the person selling or otherwise furnishing such cigarettes or tobacco related objects to request to see and to be furnished with proper identification as defined in this article in order to verify the age of such person; provided, further, that the failure to make such request and verification in any case where the person to whom the cigarettes or tobacco related objects are sold or otherwise furnished is less than 18 years of age may be considered by the trier of fact in determining whether the person selling or otherwise furnishing such cigarettes or tobacco related objects did so knowingly. (3) Any person who violates this subsection shall be guilty of a violation of this article and subject to punishment pursuant to section 1-11. (b) (1) It shall be unlawful for any minor to: A. Purchase any cigarettes or tobacco related objects. This subparagraph shall not apply to possession of cigarettes or tobacco related objects by a minor when a parent or guardian of such minor gives the cigarettes or tobacco related objects to the minor and possession is in the home or the parent or guardian and such parent or guardian is present; or B. Misrepresent such minor's identity or age or use any false identification for the purpose of purchasing or procuring any cigarettes or tobacco related objects. (2) A minor who commits an offense provided for in paragraph (b)(1) of this section may be punished as follows: A. By requiring the performance of community service not exceeding 20 hours; B. By requiring attendance at a publicly or privately sponsored lecture or discussion on the health hazards of smoking or tobacco use, provided such lecture or discussion is offered without charge to the minor; or C. By a combination of the punishments described in subparagraphs (A) and (B) of this paragraph. (Ord. No. 98-5, § II, 3-17-1998) Sec. 42-257. - Posting of signs in place of business. (a) Any person owning or operating a place of business in which cigarettes, tobacco products, or tobacco related objects are sold or offered for sale shall post in a conspicuous place a sign which shall contain the following statement: Sale of cigarettes, tobacco, tobacco products, or tobacco related objects to persons under 18 years of age is prohibited by law. Such sign shall be printed in letters of at least one-half inch in height. (b) Any person who fails to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a violation of this article and subject to punishment pursuant to section 1-11. (Ord. No. 98-5, § III, 3-17-1998) Sec. 42-258. - Sales from vending machines. In areas which are in the immediate vicinity, plain view, and under the continuous supervision of the proprietor of the establishment or an employee who will observe the purchase of cigarettes, tobacco products, and tobacco related objects from the vending machine; and C. In rest areas adjacent to roads and highways of the state. (2) Violation of this subsection shall be subject to punishment pursuant to section 1-11, provided, however, for a first offense, the sentence shall be a fine not to exceed $300.00. (Ord. No. 98-5, § IV, 3-17-1998) Secs. 42-259—42-266. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - PARKS[7]

Sec. 42-267. - Definitions. As used in this article, the term "park" or "recreational area" means a park or recreational area which is under the custody or control of the city or the county board of commissioners, whether owned or leased by the city or the county board of commissioners, and which is used for recreation by the general public. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 7-18-2000) Sec. 42-268. - Prohibited acts. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, in any manner, to mark on, deface, injure, displace, dig, excavate, remove, or construct on any real or personal property in any park or recreational area, except when done with the written permission of the city council, the county board of commissioners or the director of the parks and recreation department. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle in excess of 15 miles per hour within 200 feet of any intensive-use area in the park. As used in this subsection, the term "vehicle" means any wheeled conveyance for the transportation of persons or materials. As used in this subsection, the term "intensive-use area" means a picnic area, a pool area, a check-in station, or a ball or sporting event field. (c) It shall be unlawful to hunt, trap, or otherwise pursue or catch any wildlife in any park or recreational area. It shall also be unlawful to shoot into a park or recreational area from beyond its boundaries. (d) It shall be unlawful for any intoxicated person to enter or remain in any park or recreational area. It shall also be unlawful for any person to consume or use alcoholic beverages or intoxicants in any park or recreational area. (e) It shall be unlawful in any park or recreational area to be under the influence of any illegal drug or to solicit the purchase of drugs or to sell drugs. (f) It shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess in any park or recreational area any fireworks, explosive, or firecrackers unless such use has been granted prior written approval by the city council or the county board of commissioners. It shall also be unlawful for any person to use or possess in any park or recreational area any firearms, bows and arrows, spring guns, air rifles, slingshots, or any other device which discharges projectiles by any means unless the device is unloaded and stored so as not to be readily accessible. (g) It shall be unlawful to bring any animals, pets, domesticated animals, or reptiles, including, without limitation, dogs and cats, into any park or recreational area, with the exception of trained guide dogs or service dogs. Certain events, however, that by their nature require the presence of animals are exempt from this prohibition, such as rodeo events, horse shows, dog shows and farm exhibitions. To be exempt, persons attending such events must have the prior written approval of the director of the parks and recreation department. (h) It shall be unlawful to refuse to leave a park or recreational area after being directed to do so by any law enforcement officer or any authorized representative of the parks and recreation department. (i) It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle overnight in any park or recreational area without the prior written approval of the director of the parks and recreation department. (j) It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle at any place within any park or recreational area where signs are placed prohibiting such parking unless displaying a valid parking permit. (k) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person to swim or wade in any lake or pond located on property belonging to the City of Jackson. (l) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person to fish in any lake or pond located on property belonging to the City of Jackson. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 7-18-2000; Ord. No. 08(01)-2012, 8-7-2012) Sec. 42-269. - Tobacco use policy. (a) The city council and the county board of commissioners have a responsibility to provide and maintain a healthful and comfortable environment for participants and spectators at the various centers, sports arenas and athletic fields utilized in the parks and recreational department programs; and the parks and recreation department has facility joint use agreements involving the city (cities) and county government and the public school system and has a responsibility to uphold the usage policies and procedures of these facility owners. Accordingly, based on these responsibilities, the use of tobacco products shall be restricted as follows: (1) In facilities owned by the city and the county board of commissioners there shall be no tobacco use: a. Inside any center or gymnasium or public area within the same. "Public area" means any area or portion thereof, to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including but not limited to lobbies, reception areas, offices and restrooms. b. On athletic fields, courts and tracks, to include the coaching areas and playing field, inside dugouts, spectator viewing areas, restrooms, concession stands or press boxes. Note: Designated smoking areas will be established for each of the outdoor athletic fields. (2) In joint-use facilities belonging to the public school system, the city (cities) or private, etc., which have their own tobacco use policies, parks and recreation participants, officials and spectators shall abide by the facility owner's policy regarding the use of tobacco products. In the absence of an owner's policy regarding tobacco use, the policies established for facilities managed by the parks and recreation department (subsection (1) above) shall be followed. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 7-18-2000) Cross reference— Prohibited acts, § 42-256. Sec. 42-270. - General penalty; continuing violations; authority granted to court. (a) The violation of any provision of this article shall be punishable in the municipal court of the city by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment in the city jail not exceeding six months or both. (b) The judge of the municipal court of the city shall have the power and authority to: (1) Impose upon persons convicted in the municipal court the fines provided for in this article, or as otherwise provided by state law; (2) Sentence such person to community service work; or (3) Impose a sentence consisting of any combination of the penalties provided for in this section. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 7-18-2000) Sec. 42-271. - Jackson Veterans Memorial Park rules and regulations. (a) Closing hours. Jackson Veterans Memorial Park shall be closed from midnight until 6:00 a.m. of each day. Fine: $125.00 (b) Functions and gatherings. Functions, gatherings or other group activities in the park area are prohibited except with written permission in advance from the council of the City of Jackson. Groups are defined as ten people or more. Such activities shall be limited to recognized organizations, residents or other groups obtaining proper city council authorization. The person named on the permit agrees to assume responsibility for the group, and shall also be responsible for clean-up of the area and for the conduct of all members of the using group. Persons requesting permission for group use must be at least 18 years of age. A police officer will be on duty if deemed necessary by the Jackson Police Department and/or city council and the user shall pay all costs associated to providing police coverage. A fee, and/or security deposit may be required to cover clean-up or any other expenses, as determined by the city council. Special functions in the park may extend beyond the normal open hours of 6:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight by permit approved by the chief of police and city council when received in advance and in writing; provided assurance of adequate supervision is made in advance. After authorized use whatsoever of the park grounds, the grounds shall be left clean and orderly. Fine: $555.00 (c) Eternal flame and fires. Interference with the eternal flame is forbidden. It shall be unlawful for any person to touch the flame for any reason. It shall be unlawful for any person to build a fire in the park. Fine: $335.00 (d) Alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession, custody or control any alcoholic beverage of any kind whatsoever in the park. It shall also be unlawful for any intoxicated person to enter or remain in the park. Fine: $260.00 (e) Admittance of pets. It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any pet into the park and let it run at large, or to leave any pet unattended. Horses and livestock are not permitted in the park. Animals in the park must be restrained. Defecation must be picked up and removed. Urination on monuments, flag poles, benches, eternal flame, light poles and podium is prohibited. Fine: $335.00 (f) Solid waste, litter control. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave any rubbish, litter, garbage, refuse, cigarette butts or debris of any nature within the park except within designated receptacles provided by the city. No person or persons shall throw or deposit any type of debris or waste material on or along any city park roadway or park. Fine: $300.00 (g) Posting, distributing circulars. It shall be unlawful for any person to post or distribute any circular or pamphlet, or place any circular or pamphlet in or on any vehicle in the park area whether the vehicle is occupied or not. Fine: $335.00 (h) Protection of vegetation. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously injure, cut down or destroy any fruit, shade or ornamental tree or shrub standing or being within the park. Fine: $555.00 (i) Vandalism. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, break down, deface or remove, or cause to be interfered with any park fixtures, grounds and property. Any damage to any park property will be considered vandalism. Fine: $1,000.00 (j) Resisting officers. It shall be unlawful for any person to disobey or disregard the orders of any police officer when commanding any person to desist in violation of any provisions of this chapter or the regulations prescribed by the city or state statutes. Fine: $805.00 (k) Tents, trailers, camping and sleeping. The erection of tents and/or parking of trailers or mobile homes in park area are prohibited. No camping or sleeping is permitted in the park. Stakes that puncture the ground are prohibited. Fine: $555.00 (l) Climbing restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person to climb on park structures or any park equipment. Fine: $225.00 (m) Discharge of firearms. It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any firearms of any description in any part of the city, or have any firearm in his possession or under his control, within the confined area of the park unless you have the written permission from the chief of police and city council. Fine: $355.00 (n) Commercial vendors. No commercial vendors will be allowed in the park. Fine: $505.00 (o) Loitering. Jackson Veterans Memorial Park has been established as a memorial. There shall be no loitering or picnicking. Fine: $125.00 (p) Solicitation. No solicitation of any type is permitted in the park. All commercial sale activities are prohibited except with the written permission of the city council. Fine: $505.00 (q) Smoking. It shall be unlawful for any person to inhale, exhale, and burn or carry any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, weed, plant or other combustible substance in any manner or in any form within the park area. Fine: $125.00 (r) Skateboards, bicycles, unlicensed motorized vehicles. With the exception of wheelchairs, all skateboards, bicycles and unlicensed motorized vehicles shall be prohibited in the park. Fine: $225.00 (s) Additions to memorial. It shall be unlawful to add anything to the memorial park without the written permission from the city council. Fine: $225.00 (t) Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this article may be cited to appear before the municipal court. Upon conviction of any violation of this article, the offender may be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 2011-11-01, 11-1-2011) Secs. 42-272—42-280. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIII. - COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION
Sec. 42-281. - Definitions. Commercial solicitation or to commercially solicit means any request made in person on a street, sidewalk, or other public place, without a permit, asking for an immediate donation of money or other thing, including the purchase of an item or service for an amount far exceeding its value, under circumstances where a reasonable person would understand that the purchase is a donation. Commercial solicitation shall not include passively standing or sitting with a sign or other indication that one is seeking donations without addressing the request to any specific person. (Ord. No. 02-03-2008, § 1(75.1), 3-4-2008) Sec. 42-282. - Commercial solicitation in certain areas. It shall be unlawful for any person to commercially solicit when the person solicited is in any of the following places within the city unless otherwise provided for in chapter 50: (1) On private property if the owner, tenant, or lawful occupant has asked the person not to solicit on the property, or has posted a sign clearly indicating that solicitations are not welcome on the property; (2) Within 15 feet of the entrance to or exit from any public toilet facility, which includes any temporary use site (port-a-toilet); (3) Within 15 feet of an automatic teller machine (ATM), provided that when an automated teller machine is located within an automated teller machine facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the automated teller machine facility; (4) Within 15 feet of the entrance to or exit from a restaurant or eating facility; (5) Within 15 feet of any pay telephone, provided that when a pay telephone is located within a telephone booth or other facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the telephone booth or facility; (6) Within 15 feet of the entrance to or exit from any government office or building; (7) From any operator of a motor vehicle that is in traffic on a public street; provided, however, that this paragraph shall not apply to services rendered in connection with emergency repairs requested by the owner or passengers of such vehicle; (8) In a parking lot or garage owned or operated by the city including entryways or exits and pay stations connected therewith; (9) Within 15 feet of the entrance to or exit from any financial institution; or (10) Within 15 feet of the entrance to or exit from any valid vendor or business location, as defined in the ordinances of the city. (Ord. No. 02-03-2008, § 1(75.2), 3-4-2008) Sec. 42-283. - Nighttime commercial solicitation. It shall be unlawful for any person to commercially solicit after sunset and before sunrise. (Ord. No. 02-03-2008, § 1(75.3), 3-4-2008) Sec. 42-284. - Aggressive solicitation. It shall be unlawful for any person to commercially solicit in any of the following manners: (1) By blocking the path of the person solicited; (2) By following or walking alongside the person solicited; (3) By using profane or abusive language, either during the solicitation or following refusal; (4) By accosting or forcing oneself upon the company of another; or (5) By any statement, gesture, or other communication which a reasonable person in the situation of the person solicited would perceive to be a threat. (Ord. No. 02-03-2008, § 1(75.4), 3-4-2008) Sec. 42-285. - False or misleading solicitation. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make any false or misleading representation in the course of soliciting a donation. False or misleading representations include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) Stating that the solicitor is from out of town and stranded when such is not true; (2) Stating or suggesting falsely that the solicitor is either a present or former member of the armed service indicated; (3) Wearing or displaying an indication of physical disability, when the solicitor does not suffer the disability indicated; (4) Use of any makeup or device to simulate a deformity; or (5) Stating that the solicitor is homeless, when he or she is not. (Ord. No. 02-03-2008, § 1(75.5), 3-4-2008) Sec. 42-286. - Penalties. Penalties for violations of this article shall be as follows: (1) First violation: a. Upon a first violation, the person accused of violating this article shall be issued a warning ticket, which shall not include a summons to appear before a court of proper jurisdiction, or shall be issued a written citation, including a summons to appear before a court of proper jurisdiction for disposition of the case. b. Upon conviction for a first violation, the violator may be sentenced to one or more of the following: direction to a community outreach services program; the performance of up to three days community service; a fine not to exceed $50.00; and/or imprisonment not to exceed 48 hours in jail. (2) Second violation: a. Upon a second violation, the person accused of violating this section shall be issued a written citation, including a summons to appear before a court of proper jurisdiction for disposition of the case. b. Upon conviction for a second violation, the violator may be sentenced to one or more of the following: direction to a community outreach services program; the performance of up to ten days of community service; a fine not to exceed $125.00; and/or imprisonment not to exceed 120 hours in jail. (3) Third and subsequent violations: a. Upon a third violation, and any subsequent violations, the person accused of violating this section shall be issued a written citation, including a summons to appear before a court of proper jurisdiction for disposition of the case. b. Upon conviction for a third offense, and subsequent violations, the violator may be sentenced to one or more of the following: direction to a community outreach services program; the performance of up to 15 days community service; a fine not to exceed $250.00; and/or imprisonment not to exceed 240 hours in jail. (4) To the extent permitted by state law, information regarding citations issued pursuant to this article shall only be kept in city files and databases. (5) To the extent permitted by state law, records related to persons to whom a citation has been issued pursuant to this article shall be automatically expunged one year after the issuance of said citation. (Ord. No. 02-03-2008, § 1(75.6), 3-4-2008) Secs. 42-287—42-290. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIV. - YARD SALES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 42-291. - Definitions. Yard sale means the casual sale of domestic and/or household items, collectables, tools, pets, clothing and other personal property from any location not zoned for retail sales and in compliance with all requirements of this Code relating to retail sales. The term "yard sale" encompasses the sale of personal items by any individual not engaged in the business of retail sales and includes activities commonly referred to as "garage sales," "rummage sales," "attic sales," "moving sales," or "estate sales." The term "yard sale" does not encompass the sale of agricultural products. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-292. - Number and length of yard sales. No property shall hold or conduct more than four yard sales per calendar year, nor shall any owner or tenant of real property allow or permit more than four yard sales per address/lot per year. No property shall hold or conduct any yard sale for more than three consecutive days. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-293. - Administration and enforcement; penalties. (a) The provisions of this article shall be administered by any of the police department officers, code enforcement or other person officially designated by the city council to enforce the provisions of the official Code of the city or this article. The police department and code enforcement officers or other person officially designated by the city council [is] authorized to enter upon private or public property to examine any yard sale and to issue any citation for a violation of this article. (b) Proceedings to enforce this article shall be tried in the municipal court. Any person, firm or corporation who pleads guilty, nolo contendere or is convicted of violating the provisions of this article may be sentenced as provided in O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20 or such other general laws as may be in the future enacted to provide for punishment and penalties that may be imposed by the municipal court of this state. Each violation of this article may be punished according to the provisions of section 1-11 of the official Code of the city. (c) In addition to its right to seek all legal and equitable remedies, the city shall have the express right to seek injunctive relief against any person holding or conducting a yard sale in violation of this article. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as granting or vesting in any person or entity other than the city, its council or agents, any right of enforcement by legal, equitable or injunctive process. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-294. - Parking of vehicles. The person in charge of the premises upon which a yard sale is conducted shall control the parking of vehicles of patrons so as to avoid congestion and hazardous conditions. Failure to do so shall be sufficient cause for the sale to be immediately terminated. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Secs. 42-295—42-300 - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 42-301. - Required. (a) Any person who owns the property upon which the yard sale will take place, any person conducting the yard sale, and any person participating as a seller in the yard sale, must obtain a permit from the city clerk prior to the date of the yard sale. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to allow, conduct or participate as a seller in a yard sale in the city without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk. (c) Each permit issued under this division must be promptly displayed on the premises upon which the yard sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the permitted sale. (d) No property can obtain more than two permits per calendar year without the required fee of $25.00. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-302. - Applications. All applications must be received by the clerk two weeks prior to yard sale. At the time any person makes a request for the issuance of a permit under this division, the clerk shall obtain the following information: (1) Name of the person that will be conducting the sale. (2) Name of the owner of the property upon which the sale will be conducted. (3) Location at which the sale will be conducted. (4) Names of any persons who will be participating as a seller in the sale. (5) Date of the sale. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-303. - Interruption of sale. If a permit holder commences a yard sale and the yard sale is interrupted or terminated for any reason, the holder of the permit shall not be allowed to restart the yard sale after the date and time permitted without obtaining a new permit. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-304. - Maximum number per calendar year. The number of yard sales allowed per calendar year period under this article is as follows: (1) Residential property. Four yard sales per year will be allowed on residentially zoned property. (2) Church/civic/nonprofit organization property. Four yard sales per year will be allowed on church, civic or nonprofit organization property. (3) Commercial/industrial property. One yard sale per year will be allowed on commercially/industrially zoned property. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-305. - Fees. (a) If the yard sale is conducted on residential property, or on church/civic/nonprofit organization property, two free permits may be obtained during a calendar year period without payment of a fee. The remaining two permits allowed per calendar year period will be issued upon payment to the clerk of a fee of $25.00. (b) If the yard sale is conducted on commercial property a permit will be issued upon payment of a fee of $25.00. A letter of approval must be presented with application from property owner/ or manager of business located on property. (c) Fees paid for a permit under this section are nonrefundable. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 ) Sec. 42-306. - Signs. (a) Signs are not permitted on the city's right-of-way or utility poles. If signs are placed on the city's right-of-way or utility poles, the person the permit is issued to will receive a city ordinance citation with a fine in the amount of $25.00 per sign. (b) Signs are not allowed to be placed on any property before 48 hours of approved yard sale or remain on property after 48 hours of yard sale. The person the permit is issued to will receive a city ordinance citation with a fine in the amount of $25.00 per sign. (c) Fees paid for a permit under this section are nonrefundable. (Ord. of 5-3-2016 )

div.head: Chapter 46 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1, the city is included in a multijurisdictional solid waste management plan prepared by the Butts County Solid Waste Management Authority dated August 25, 1992, for Butts County, Jackson, Jenkinsburg and Flovilla. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; litter control, § 34-171 et seq.; utilities, ch. 66. State Law reference— Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local, multijurisdictional and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 46-1—46-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Scrap tire disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.1; yard trimmings disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.2; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries without permission, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249; transportation of medical waste, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-253.1.
Sec. 46-31. - Curbside limited waste collection services supplied by city or waste collection franchisee; fees. (a) The city shall provide limited waste collection services at curbside for consumers, in the following categories: (1) Vegetation waste. Vegetation waste shall be defined as tree limbs, leaves, shrubs, brush trimmings, and grass, taken from the property at which curbside service is being provided at no charge to customers. Limbs, trees, or parts of trees removed from the property by contractors will not be removed by the city. All contractors must make arrangements for disposal of trees or limbs before commencing work. (2) Discarded furniture. Discarded furniture shall not include metal furniture, appliances or large items of electronic equipment. Customers will be charged a minimum fee of $25.00 up to a maximum fee of $100.00 for removal of all other furniture items. (b) The city and/or a waste collection franchisee shall also provide limited waste collection services at curbside for consumers in the following category: rubbish, defined as printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and boots, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances, combustible waste pulp, and other products which are used for packaging or wrapping crockery and glass. Customers may be charged a fee up to $100.00; no charge for piles less than four feet by eight feet by five feet, $50.00 charge for piles larger than four feet by eight feet by five feet, and $100.00 charge for piles larger than six feet by ten feet. (c) The city and/or a waste collection franchisee shall provide the services described in subsections (a) and (b) of this section at a charge of $25.00 to $100.00 only to those city customers who select the curbside waste collection and pay a monthly fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, to either the city or to the city's franchisee. Those city customers not selecting the curbside collection from either the city or the city's franchisee and not paying a monthly fee to either the city or the city's franchisee will be charged a fee of $200.00 for the services described in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. (Ord. No. 96-7, §§ I—III, 1-2-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 46-32. - Waste collection franchisee; fee required; enumeration of waste materials not covered by fee. After the city has contracted with a waste collection franchisee, the name, location and telephone number of franchisee shall be made available to all citizens. Each city utility customer selecting the service directly from the city shall pay a monthly fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for curbside waste collection to the city, and the city shall pay a monthly fee from such monthly fees to the franchisee for weekly curbside collection of garbage properly disposed of in carts or containers provided by the franchisee. The monthly fee paid by the customer does not include collection of the types of waste material described in this section. Citizens or residents must contract directly with a waste disposal franchisee or otherwise privately handle disposal of these types of waste material: (1) Bulky waste. Bulky waste shall include stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, clothes dryers, television sets, washing machines, and other similar items. (2) Construction debris. Construction debris, whether discarded by a homeowner, occupant, or professional contractor, shall include waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair, or demolition operations. (3) Hazardous waste. Hazardous waste includes waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal, state or local law, or waste, in any amount, which is regulated under federal, state or local law. The term "hazardous waste" shall also include batteries, tires, petroleum products, paint and paint cans, except completely empty paint cans, and such items containing chlorofluorocarbon refrigerants or freon. (4) Dead animals. All animals, large or small. (Ord. No. 96-7, § IV, 1-2-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 46-33. - Duties and responsibilities of real estate owners or occupants concerning collection. Owners of real estate or occupants of real estate within the city limits shall have the following duties and responsibilities concerning waste collection: (1) Placement at curbside; removal; violation constitutes littering; exceptions. A garbage curbside collection franchisee shall notify its customers of the time that it will empty carts or containers. It will be the customer's responsibility to place a cart at curbside prior to collection and to remove the cart from curbside after collection. If any residential cart is left at curbside or upon the city's right-of-way for more than 48 hours following the day of cart trash collection by the franchisee, such act shall be an act of littering. Any owner or occupant of real estate cited for a violation of this section may show as a defense extenuating circumstances which make strict enforcement unreasonable, such as extreme weather conditions, absence from the city for a reasonable period of time, or temporary physical disability. Persons with long-term physical disability are required to contract with a franchisee for backdoor collection, or contract privately for moving the cart. (2) Bulky waste, construction debris and hazardous waste; separate contract required; accumulations constitute littering. Those items described in section 46-32 as bulky waste, construction debris, hazardous waste and dead animals are items which the city will not collect, and a waste disposal franchisee is not required to collect for the monthly fee automatically added to city utility bills or the monthly fee billed directly by the franchisee. Any owner or occupant of premises within the city that has such waste to dispose of must either contract directly with a franchisee or privately remove such waste. If any such waste is allowed to accumulate on private premises or allowed to remain at curbside for a period of ten days, such accumulation shall be an act of littering. (3) Accumulation of solid waste constitutes littering. Each city utility customer not selecting the curbside waste collection service directly from the city or the city's franchisee and not paying a monthly fee either directly to the city or to the city's franchisee, who allows any type of solid waste to accumulate on private premises or allows it to remain at curbside for a period of ten days, shall be guilty of an act of littering. (4) Citation for littering; penalty for violation of section. When any act of littering is committed in violation of this article, a citation may be issued to any owner of the premises, whether or not the owner is in actual possession of the premises, or any occupant of the premises who is either a head of household or a manager or officer of a business. Separate citations for littering may be issued to as many persons as are deemed responsible by virtue of this article. Such citations shall be tried before the municipal court of the city. Violators of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11 (Ord. No. 96-7, § V, 1-2-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 46-34. - On-site dumpster requirements. The city council hereby requires that all subdivisions of three or more lots where construction is occurring shall be required to have one on-site dumpster or use of a dump truck and a porta-toilet, and for each additional five lots or fractions thereof where construction is occurring, an additional dumpster or dump truck and a porta-toilet shall be required. (Ord. No. 99-11, 12-7-1999; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-11, adopted December 7, 1999, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as § 46-34 was at the discretion of the editor. Cross reference— Subdivisions, ch. 54. Secs. 46-35—46-44. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - YARD TRIMMINGS
Sec. 46-45. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to prohibit the inclusion of yard trimmings in municipal solid waste; to establish the manner of sorting, storing, composting and collecting yard trimmings; to provide penalties; and for other purposes. (Ord. No. 96-34, 10-15-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 46-46. - Definitions. Commercial solid waste. All types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. Composting. The controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. Leachate collection system. A system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. Municipal solid waste. Any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. Municipal solid waste disposal facility. Any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. Municipal solid waste landfill. A disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludge's or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. Yard trimmings. Leaves, acorns, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree pruning's, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Ord. No. 96-34, art. I, 10-15-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 46-47. - Placement and disposal of yard trimmings; prohibitions. (a) It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the city. (b) Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city. (Ord. No. 96-34, art. II, 10-15-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 46-48. - Collecting yard trimmings. Yard trimmings shall be sorted and stored in the following manner: vegetation waste, which shall be defined as tree limbs, leaves, acorns, shrubs, brush trimmings, and grass, taken from the property at which curbside service is being provided, items must be cut less than six 6 feet in length. Shall be picked up at curbside by the city for consumers paying the monthly fees. Excluding limbs, trees, or parts of trees removed from the property by contractors, all contractors must make arrangements for disposal of trees or limbs before commencing work. (Ord. No. 96-34, art. III, 10-15-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 46-49. - Penalties. Any person violating section 46-48 of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed six months or both. (Ord. No. 96-34, art. IV, 10-15-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 )

div.head: Chapter 50 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; cable communications, ch. 22; environment, ch. 34; subdivisions, ch. 54; traffic and vehicles, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 66; vegetation, ch. 70; zoning, ch. 74. State Law reference— Municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; grant by municipal corporation of right to obstruct public street prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10; power of city to open, close or extend public streets, alleys and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; municipal street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; executions for collection of municipal assessments for paving streets and laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 50-1—50-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARADES AND DEMONSTRATIONS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Preventing or disrupting lawful procession, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34; funeral processions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-76; operation of motorcycles and motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 50-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Fund-raising events are sponsored by local non-profit or local civic groups. The solicitation of funds and sale of goods must be a direct service or a direct financial benefit to the citizens of the city. A signed affidavit from the sponsoring group must accompany the application. Group demonstration means an assembling together or concert of action between or among two or more persons for the purpose of protesting any matter or of making known any position or of promotion of such persons, or on behalf of any organization or class of persons, or for the purpose of attracting attention to such assembly. Minor child means any unemancipated person below the age of 18 years. Outdoor group assembly means any outdoor church service, circus, performance, carnival, speech, debate or rally, which would be reasonably anticipated to gather 50 or more people in an outdoor setting and is either held in any public place or is held upon private property not open to the public and will produce sounds which would be clearly audible to persons located outside of the premises or boundaries of the lot or tract of real estate upon which such gathering takes place. Parade means any march, ceremony, show, exhibition or procession of any kind in or upon the public streets, sidewalks, parks or other public places, and shall generally be considered to be a group demonstration traveling along a specific route. Parade chairperson or activity chairperson means a person to whom any permit, as provided in this article, is issued. Picket means any individual participating in a picket line. Picket line means any two or more persons picketing together for the purpose of making known any position of or protest by such persons, or on behalf of any organization, person, or class of persons, and shall generally be considered to be a parade in which the individuals involved cover the same route more than once. Sidewalk means that portion of the street, public easement or right-of-way lying between the portion thereof used primarily for vehicular traffic and the property line abutting such street, public easement or right-of-way. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. I(A), 5-21-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 50-32. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish rules and regulations for parades, fund-raising event, group demonstrations, picketing, group assembly and other like assemblage and to provide for permits and to prohibit all such demonstrations without same. (Ord. No. 96-25, 5-21-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 50-33. - Designation and duties of person in charge. Any permit issued pursuant to the requirements of this article shall designate the person in charge of the activity. That person shall accompany the activity and shall carry the permit on his person at all times. The permit shall not be valid in the possession of any other person. This person shall be called the parade chairperson or activity chairperson. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. I(B), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-34. - Prohibited activities. When performed or undertaken in conjunction with or as a part of, any parade, picket line, fund-raising event, group demonstration or outdoor group assembly, it shall be unlawful: (1) To conduct any parade, fund-raising event, group demonstration, picket or outdoor group assembly without first obtaining a written permit for such activity. (2) To include livestock at any event unless approved by city council. (3) To carry on or about the person, or on or about any vehicle, any firearm or explosive compound or all of the components of any firearm or explosive compound. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. I(C), 5-21-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 50-35. - Deviation from permit. No person shall cause, participate in, lead or encourage any parade, picket line or group demonstration which deviates in any manner from the location or method of demonstration specified in the permit. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. I(D), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-36. - Disruption or interference offenses. (a) No person shall hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any event being conducted under authority of a duly issued permit. (b) No person participating in or observing any activity conducted under a permit issued under the provisions of this article shall make any loud or sharp noise by use of any mechanical or pyrotechnical device. Only the sounds of the unamplified human voice will be permitted, unless same is specifically allowed by the written permit issued in advance of the activity. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. I(E), 5-21-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Sec. 50-37. - Traffic and crowd control Such traffic and crowd control on the public property, streets, sidewalks and right-of-way lying within the city as may be deemed appropriate by the mayor and city council shall be provided by the city, a fee may be charged by the city for this service. (Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Editor's note— An ordinance of April 19, 2016, repealed former § 50-37, which pertained to horses, cows, goats, etc., and derived from Ord. No. 96-25, adopted May 21, 1996. The ordinance of April 19, 2016 also added new provisions, which have been designated as § 50-37 at the discretion of the editor. Sec. 50-38. - Throwing objects. When a parade involves motor vehicles of any sort, or wagons, no person shall throw or dispense toys, tokens, candy, trinkets or any object in such a manner as may entice children or other persons into the streets. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. I(G), 5-21-1996; Ord. of 4-19-2016 ) Secs. 50-39—50-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PICKETING
Sec. 50-61. - Statement of purpose. Peaceful picketing in the furtherance of a lawful purpose shall be permitted in the city. The standards and regulations in this division are promulgated for the regulation of such picketing. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(A), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-62. - Picketing permit. A permit to picket shall contain all the information and be subject to all the constraints as a normal parade permit except as specified in this division. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(B), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-63. - Rules for picketing. (a) There shall be no more than 15 persons actively picketing under one picketing permit at the same time. (b) At no time will picketing be allowed on both sides of the street at the same time within any given block. The purpose of this rule is to allow the sidewalk or sidewalk area of at least one side of the street to be free of picketers for regular pedestrian traffic at all times. (c) Pickets must march in single file and not abreast and may not march closer together than ten feet except in passing one another. (d) Pickets shall be in continuous motion. (e) Pickets may carry written or printed placards or signs not exceeding two feet in width and two feet in length promoting the objective for which the picketing is done. The staff on any such placard or sign shall not exceed 40 inches in length, must be made of wood, shall not exceed three-fourths of an inch in diameter or on any side at any point and must be blunt at each end. (f) Picketing shall not be conducted on the portion of a street used primarily for vehicular traffic, nor in any public building. (g) No picket shall make or produce loud or unusual noise, including but not limited to shouting, clapping or singing, of such a nature as to or be likely to disturb the peace and tranquility of persons inside buildings or otherwise to unreasonably interfere with personal or commercial businesses and activities of the people of the city. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(C), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-64. - Use of force or threats to compel continuance in or departure from employment. It shall be unlawful for any person, acting alone or in concert with one or more other persons, by the use of force, intimidation, violence or threats thereof, to prevent or attempt to prevent any individual from leaving or continuing in the employment of or from accepting or refusing employment by an employer or from entering or leaving any place of employment of such employer. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(D), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-65. - Unlawful assemblages near site of labor dispute. It shall be unlawful for any person acting in concert with one or more other persons to assemble at or near any place where a labor dispute exists, and by force, intimidation, violence or threats thereof, to prevent or attempt to prevent any person from engaging in any lawful vocation or for any person acting either by himself, or as a member of any group or organization or acting in concert with one or more other persons, to promote, encourage or aid in such unlawful assemblage. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(E), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-66. - Interference with public ways of travel, transportation or conveyance by mass picketing near site of labor dispute. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in mass picketing at or near any place where a labor dispute exists in such number or manner as to obstruct or interfere with or constitute a threat to obstruct or interfere with the entrance to or egress from any place of employment or the free and uninterrupted use of public roads, streets, highways, railroads, airports or other ways of travel, transportation or conveyance. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(F), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-67. - Limitations upon freedom of speech. No person shall at any time within the city speak or display upon a sign opprobrious or abusive words, which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace, that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person, in a manner intended to communicate same to such other person, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words." (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(G), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-68. - Counter-picketing. If pickets promoting different or opposite objectives apply for permits to use the same sidewalks for picketing and such use would result in the presence of more than 15 pickets upon the same sidewalks, the city clerk shall place time limitations upon the permit allowing each group an equal amount of time upon the sidewalk during the daylight hours. (Ord. No. 96-25, art. II(H), 5-21-1996) Sec. 50-69. - Interference with pickets. (a) No person shall physically interfere with persons engaged in peaceful picketing pursuant to a permit granted by the city clerk, nor shall any person address to any picket opprobrious or abusive words which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace, that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person in such other person's presence, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words." (b) If persons assemble in such numbers as to tend to intimidate pickets pursuing their lawful objective through numbers alone or through use of inflammatory words, then the police may direct the dispersal of such persons so assembled, and may arrest any person who fails to absent himself from the place of such assemblage when so directed by the police. No person so assembled shall fail to absent himself from such place or to cease and desist from such course of conduct after having been directed by the police to do so. (c) Any event which is to use a portion of any state highway right-a-way lying within the city must also have obtained all required permits from the state department of transportation. It shall be the applicant's sole duty and responsibility to obtain all such permits prior to making application to the city for any special event permit. No city special event permit shall be issued without the proper state department of transportation permit first having been obtained, and a copy of same filed with the city clerk with the application for the event permit. (d) Any event which is to use private property within the city must also obtain a written letter of approval from the property owner or business located at the property.
