Sec. 66-221. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City means the mayor and city council of the city, and its agents and employees. Consumer means any person, corporation, partnership, joint venture or public body that uses, has use of, has use for or seeks to use water furnished by the city or its agents. Developer means any person, corporation, partnership, joint venture, public body or legal entity that is selling, offering for sale, dividing, subdividing or developing property for residential, commercial or industrial use. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 1, 5-7-1996) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 66-222. - Enforcement of article. The city shall enforce the terms of this article through the administrative procedures set out in this article through legal actions in a court of law. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 14, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-223. - Application for water service. (a) Initial application. Any consumer or developer desiring to be provided water services through the city's water lines shall make an application for water services in person at city hall. The owner of the property or structure to be served is responsible for the application. (b) Line availability. If the water distribution system includes a water line adjacent to, or directly across the road from, the consumer's property, and no water line extension is required, service will be provided upon the customer executing a service contract and paying the required service connection fee and meter installation fee. (c) Enlargement of water lines; costs. If the city determines that it is in the best interest of the city to enlarge the water lines and water system facilities from the owner/developer's property line to the water system facilities, the owner/developer will be responsible for 100 percent of the costs for the increased size of water line and water facilities. (d) Installation list. Upon complying with subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the consumer will be placed on the meter installation list. The connection and the meter will be installed by the city, or its agent, as soon as practicable thereafter. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 2, 5-7-1996; Amend. of 6-3-1997, § 12) Sec. 66-224. - City's responsibilities and liabilities. (a) Water connection line. Upon the consumer meeting the requirements of section 66-223, the city will run a water connection line to the property of the consumer. The water connection will include a curb stop valve, meter and meter box. In addition, a pressure reducer will be installed when average line pressure at the connection exceeds 90 psi. (b) Site of meter. The city may install its meter at or near the property line, or at the city's option, on the consumer's property within three feet of the property line. (c) Initiation of service. When the consumer has connected his piping to the meter, the city will inspect the connection and turn on water service. Under no circumstances shall the consumer operate the curb stop valve on the downstream side of the meter. (d) Right to refuse service. The city reserves the right to refuse service unless the consumer's lines and piping are installed in conformity with the city's specifications and the regulations of the current plumbing code in the city and the county. (e) Interruptions of service. Under normal conditions, the consumer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the city. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 3, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-225. - Consumer's responsibilities and liabilities. (a) Water use. Water furnished by the city shall be used for consumption by the consumer, members of the household, employees and/or visitors only. The consumer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. The consumer shall not allow anyone else to connect onto the water system serving the consumer. Water shall not be used for irrigation, or other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interference with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard of this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal and/or discontinuance of service. (b) Access to meter. Where the meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a consumer, a suitable place shall be provided by the consumer therefor, which is unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. (c) Consumer's cut-off valve. The consumer shall furnish and maintain a private cut-off valve on the consumer's side of the meter within the meter box. (d) Backflow prevention device. The consumer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer at the consumer's expense so as to prevent a backflow by use of an approved backflow prevention device. Under normal conditions, the backflow prevention device must be located within the meter box to allow for regular testing of its functioning. (e) Pressure release device. The consumer shall furnish and maintain an approved pressure relief device on a cold water line on the consumer's side of the meter. This pressure relief device shall not be located in the meter box. (f) Disconnection of wells. (1) No physical connection. In order to be received as a consumer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system. All applicants, by becoming consumers of the city, covenant and agree that, so long as they continue to be consumers of the city, they will not permit the connection of any private wells to the authority's water system. (2) Sealing of certain wells. In areas designated on an individual lot-by-lot basis, all existing wells must be disconnected, filled, sealed and plugged from further use, in accordance with the state department of natural resources and county board of health regulations, and no new wells may be bored or drilled. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 4, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-226. - Access to consumer's premises by agents and employees of the city. Duly authorized agents and employees of the city shall have access at all reasonable hours to the premises of the consumer and/or property owner for the purposes of installing and removing the property of the city, inspecting the city's facilities, reading and testing meters and repairing and maintaining the facilities of the city. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 5, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-227. - Fees for water service. (a) Charges for initial water service. Each consumer subscribing for uses of water services through the city shall pay a nonrefundable connection fee. (See appendix to Ordinance No. 96-4 and 96-10 for charges.) (b) Meter for each unit. A separate meter is required for each individual dwelling unit and/or unit of business. All multiunit commercial or professional buildings shall have a meter installed for each unit. All multifamily dwellings shall have a meter installed for each unit. The prevailing service connection fee and meter installation fee shall be paid for each unit. (c) Fire line installation. All individual dwelling units and/or units of business including all multiunit commercial or professional buildings that require fire installation must install a meter or backflow preventer or a detection check valve. All consumers who install a fire line will be required to pay the minimum monthly charge as set by the city commencing on the next billing date after the meter and a backflow preventer or a check detection valve are set and water is available. (See appendix to Ordinance No. 96-4 and 96-10 for charges.) (d) Deposits. The city is authorized to establish deposit fees to be paid for water and sewer service and to collect such fees upon application for service and at such other times as the city may determine to be necessary. For rental property, tenants will be required to pay the established deposit fee. When a tenant moves out, the deposit, less any amount owed, will be refunded to the tenant. If service is not shut off at the meter, a regular deposit will be required from the property owner. (See appendix to Ordinance No. 96-4 and 96-10 for charges.) (e) Water rates. The rate schedule used for the city is set from time to time. However, water rates will not increase without 30 days' notice to the consumer. Notice will be sufficiently given to the consumer by a publication of the rate changes at least one time in the official newspaper of the county prior to the rate increase. Property owners shall be responsible for any unpaid water bills. (See appendix A to Ordinance No. 96-10 for current rates.) (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 6, 5-7-1996; Amend. of 6-3-1997, §§ 13—17) Sec. 66-228. - Meter designations/readings. (a) Reading schedule. The water meter serving the consumer's property shall be read on a monthly basis and official records of each reading thereof shall be kept for a period of one year. (b) Meter designation. Water meters shall be classified as either active meters, inactive meters and canceled meters. These designations are defined as follows: (1) Active meters are defined as meters that are in normal use. All active meters will be charged on a monthly basis. (2) Inactive meters are defined as meters that are installed where the consumer has notified the city in writing to temporarily terminate service. When it receives such written request, the city will seal the meter and declare the meter an inactive meter. When no responsible party is available to request inactive meter designation for the consumer, the city may declare the meter inactive. If a consumer desires to obtain water services after the meter has been declared inactive, the consumer shall pay the city a deposit and reconnection fee. In addition, the consumer must pay any previous unpaid bills which that consumer had through the city's services prior to obtaining any additional service from the city. Once the deposit, connection fee and any past due bills have been paid, the meter will be reclassified as an active meter as defined in subsection (b)(1) of this section. (3) Canceled meters are defined as meters that have not been in use where the consumer has notified the city that no further water service from the city is desired. The city may, on its own initiative, declare a meter canceled when water has not been used for a period of 12 months or longer, excluding fire lines. If a meter is declared a canceled meter, the meter will be removed and the connection sealed. A consumer desiring reconnection of a canceled meter shall pay the deposit and connection fee that is in effect as of the date of application. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 7, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-229. - Billings and collections. (a) Payment. The consumer shall pay promptly on a monthly basis for all water registered by the meter serving such property at the rates set by the city from time to time, which shall include water used, water wasted or leakage, except for the water that may be traced by the city to the city's system. (b) Billing schedule. Bills are sent out on the first day of each month. Bills shall be paid by the tenth day of each month. Payments received after the tenth will be assessed a ten percent late fee. If no payment is received, service will be discontinued on the 21st day of the month. If water service is disconnected for nonpayment of the bill, the city will not resume water service to the consumer until the bill, reconnection fees and all penalties have been paid in full. If the tenth day of the month falls on a Saturday, Sunday or a holiday, when city hall is closed, payments will be accepted without late charge on the following workday when city hall is open. (c) Billing errors. If the consumer believes his bill to be in error, this claim must be presented to the city, or its billing agent, before the bill becomes due. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as provided in this section. The customer may pay such bill under protest and such payment shall not prejudice his claim. Any consumer who fails to notify the city in writing within 30 days after the date of such bill of any irregularities or errors that may be in such bill shall waive any right or claim for correction or refund under such bill. (d) Meter failure. If the seal of a meter is broken by any person other than the city's representative, or if the meter fails to register correctly, or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount which is the average for the preceding month's water usage. (e) Meter testing and rechecks. The city will carry out a regular program of meter testing and replacement. In addition, water meters will be tested at the request of the consumer. The city may make a charge for a consumer requested meter recheck. (See appendix to Ordinance No. 96-4 and 96-10 for charges.) (f) Fee for bad checks. Consumers who make payments with checks which are not covered by sufficient funds will be charged a bad check fee as set by the city. When a consumer has written a check which has been returned for insufficient funds, the city will accept only cash or money orders for the next 12 months. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 8, 5-7-1996; Amend. of 6-3-1997, § 17) Sec. 66-230. - Suspension of services. (a) Refund of deposit. When water service is discontinued either by written notice from the consumer to the city, or by acts of the city, or its agents, the city shall apply any refundable deposits held to the balance of the bill owed by the consumer and refund the difference, if any exists, to the consumer. The city will not add accrued interest earned to any consumer refunds. (b) Termination without notice. The city reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following reasons: (1) For emergency repairs. (2) For want of supply beyond the city's control. (3) For nonpayment of a service bill. (4) On account of, or to prevent, fraud. (5) For a violation by the customer of any provision of this article. (6) Insufficiency of sewage treatment facility. (7) Legal processes. (8) Direction of public authorities. (9) Acts of God. (c) Other terminations. The city reserves the right to terminate the services granted by the city for any other reason other than those stated in this section by giving the consumer ten days' written notice of the date of termination, and further providing the consumer with a right to hearing prior to termination. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 9, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-231. - Allocation of water services. The city shall have the right from time to time, if necessary, to allocate water to the consumer. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 10, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-232. - Line extensions. (a) Plans and specifications for construction of water lines. The city shall have the right to specify the requirements, plans and specifications for construction of water lines in the city. All water lines constructed, or paid for, by the city, utility, contractor, consumer, owner or developer shall be constructed according to the plans and specifications established by the city for the construction of water lines in the city. No water line shall be covered without first being inspected and approved by the city. (b) Right-of-way. Water lines may be extended along city streets which have sufficient dedicated right-of-way. (c) Ownership of lines. All water lines built will become the property of the city. (d) Water line extensions and increase in size of existing and/or new water lines to serve residential, commercial, and industrial development. This section applies to new residential subdivisions, industrial sites and commercial sites and to necessary extensions of existing and/or new water lines along existing public streets to reach those sites. The owner of the new development shall be required to pay the full cost for labor, materials, design, and all other cost of water line extensions. If the city determines that it is in the best interest of the city to increase the size of the existing water lines serving the new development, the owner of the new development shall be required to pay the full cost for labor, materials, design, and all other cost for the increase in the size of the existing water lines. Line construction must adhere strictly to adopted city specifications. Extensions and increase in size of existing and/or new water lines to a new development will be considered under the following conditions: (1) Right-of-way. Sufficient dedicated right-of-way must be available along city streets required to access the development. (2) [Zoning.] The developer must provide a letter from the zoning enforcement officer or his/her designee that the property has been properly zoned for the proposed use. (3) Construction plans. The developer must provide the city with three copies of a plat or accurate drawing of the property to be served. Such plats or drawings shall contain the following information: a. Location of the closest existing water line of the city which is of sufficient size to serve the property; b. Location of the existing and proposed roads to serve the property; c. Exact footage of water line that will have to be installed in order to serve the property; d. Location of all water lines and appurtenances to be constructed in the area to be developed; and e. Documentation that lines and appurtenances have been sized to meet the city's specifications for consumer demand and fire flows. (4) Financial documentation. The developer must document financial ability to pay the cost of construction and must deposit required connection fees with the city. (5) City approval. Once items in subsections (d)(1) through (4) of this section are completed, the request will be submitted to the city council for its approval. (6) Construction by developer. Lines will normally be allowed to be constructed by the developer only within the development itself. In such instances, the developer must submit copies of construction plans conforming to city specifications to the city for review. During construction, the city will inspect work as necessary. (7) Other items to be considered. Upon completion of construction by the developer, but prior to the initiation of water service the following must be done: a. The city will conduct tests to ensure that completed water lines meet city specifications for pressure, flow and water quality. b. The developer must post a deed conveying the water line, appurtenances thereto and any required permanent easements to the city. c. The developer must post a surety bond, or letter of credit from any banking institution within the state with the city in the amount of ten percent of the total cost of the construction of such line, which such bond, or letter of credit, shall guarantee payment to the city for any repairs or maintenance needed in such line over a period of one year from the date of conveyance of such line. d. The developer must furnish three copies of as-built water lines and appurtenances. e. The developer must execute an affidavit prescribed by the city stating that the cost of all labor and materials has been paid; accompanied by copies of all invoices. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 11, 5-7-1996; Ord. No. 2-12-2007, § 1, 12-27-2007) Sec. 66-233. - Tampering with city property. (a) Prohibited actions. Any consumer or person who without the authorization of the city: (1) Connects onto a water line of the city; (2) Disconnects a water line from a water line of the city; (3) Connects onto a water meter of the city; (4) Disconnects a water meter of the city; (5) Moves, removes, changes or alters the location of a water meter; (6) Changes, alters or damages any water meter or water line so as to prevent proper registration of water passing through such water meter or line; (7) Obtains water; (8) Prevents any other person from obtaining water; (9) Obstructs, or otherwise interferes, with the reading or maintenance of any water meter; (10) Obstructs or otherwise interferes with water line, fire hydrant, pumping station or any appurtenances to water facilities of the city; (11) Creates a hazardous or unsafe condition to the water facilities of the city; or (12) Constructs a water line without approval of plans and specifications by the city; shall be issued a citation, and if found guilty, shall be subject to a minimum fine of $250.00, to a maximum fine of $500.00 plus damages and/or imprisonment in the city jail for a minimum of 30 days to a maximum of six months. (b) Court of jurisdiction. The municipal court of the city shall have jurisdiction to hear, try and dispose of citations that are issued for such violations. (c) Issuance of citation. All consumers or persons who are charged with having violated this article shall be issued a citation by the city police department or a representative of the city. The citation shall require the appearance of the violator in the municipal court of the city to answer said charges. (d) Reward for information. The city may pay a reward for any information leading to the issuance of a citation and conviction of any consumer or person found to have engaged in any of the prohibited actions listed in subsection (a) of this section. The amount of reward will be set by the city. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 12, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-234. - Fire hydrant water use. (a) Permit. A fire hydrant water use permit is required for each separate occasion where water will be taken from a hydrant. The permit will indicate the hydrant location, the date used and the estimated number of gallons. (b) Metering. Except as approved by the city, all water taken from fire hydrants must be measured through the city's meter. A meter deposit of $50.00 is required each time the meter is used. This deposit will be refunded immediately upon return of the meter in good condition. (c) Approved container. All tanks, tanker trucks, seed spraying trucks and other containers which will be filled with water must obtain an approved certificate of inspection for hydrant use which verifies that the container is equipped with a permanent approved air gap or reduced pressure zone backflow prevention device. The fee for inspection is $10.00 per vehicle and is good for a period of one year. (d) Hoses and connections. Hoses connected to a fire hydrant for purposes other than filling an inspected and approved container shall not be submerged and/or left unsecured in a pool, pond, lake or container at any time while attached to the hydrant. A minimum air gap equal to two times the outlet diameter of the hose shall be maintained at all times above the pool or container overflow level. Under no condition will more than one of the 2½-inch connections on the fire hydrant be allowed for use at any time with each issued permit. (e) Hydrant operation. Persons using fire hydrants will be instructed on proper hydrant use by the city. Any damage done to the hydrant will be the responsibility of the party using the hydrant. (f) Billing. The party taking water from a hydrant will be billed directly by the city for water used at the standing rate for hydrant water use. No second-party billing will be made. Any water distributed from the hydrant at the city fire department must be paid for at the time of distribution. (See appendix A of Ordinance No. 96-10 for hydrant usage rates.) (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 13, 5-7-1996) Sec. 66-235. - Amendments to article. This article may be amended by the city council. Notice of the proposed amendment must be advertised at least one time in the legal newspaper of the county prior to final vote on adoption of any such amendment. (Ord. No. 96-10, art. 15, 5-7-1996) Secs. 66-236—66-240. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, adopted October 21, 2008, enacted provisions which were not specifically amendatory of the Code and have been included herein as a new art. IV, §§ 66-241—66-252, at the editors' discretion.
Sec. 66-241. - Short title. This article shall be known as the identity theft prevention program. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-242. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to comply with 16 CFR § 681.2 in order to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-243. - Definitions. For purposes of this article, the following definitions apply: City means the City of Jackson. Covered account means (i) An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and (ii) Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or litigation risks. Credit means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefore. Creditor means any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies. Customer means a person that has a covered account with a creditor. Identity theft means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority. Person means a natural person, a corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, trust, estate, partnership, cooperative, or association. Personal identifying information means a person's credit card account information, debit card information bank account information and drivers' license information and for a natural person includes their social security number, mother's birth name, and date of birth. Red flag means a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. Service provider means a person that provides a service directly to the city. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-244. - Findings. (a) The city is a creditor pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.2 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in arrears. (b) Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of city services include water, sewer, electric and garbage (c) The processes of opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account and making payments on such accounts. (d) The city limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts. (e) The city determines that there is a low risk of identity theft occurring in the following ways: (1) Use by an applicant of another person's personal identifying information to establish a new covered account; (2) Use of a previous customer's personal identifying information by another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customer's name; (3) Use of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customer's covered account or accounts; (4) Use by a customer desiring to restore such customer's covered account with another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment; (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-245. - Process of establishing a covered account. As a precondition to opening a covered account in the city, each applicant shall provide the city with personal identifying information of the customer including government issued ID, valid driver's license, and social security number. Such applicant shall also provide any information necessary for the department providing the service for which the covered account is created to access the applicant's consumer credit report. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-246. - Access to covered account information. (a) Access to customer accounts shall be password protected and shall be limited to authorized city personnel. (b) Such password(s) shall be changed by the utility manager on a regular basis, shall be at least eight characters in length and shall contain letters, numbers and symbols. (c) Any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to be reported immediately to the utility manager and the password changed immediately. (d) Personal identifying information included in customer accounts is considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be immediately forwarded to the city attorney. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-247. - Credit card payments. (a) In the event that credit card payments that are made over the Internet are processed through a third party service provider, such third party service provider shall certify that it has an adequate identity theft prevention program in place that is applicable to such payments. (b) All credit card payments made over the telephone or the city's website shall be entered directly into the customer's account information in the computer data base. (c) Account statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account used for payment of the covered account. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-248. - Sources and types of red flags. All employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a covered account, restoring a covered account, or accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags may include: (1) Alerts from consumer reporting agencies, fraud detection agencies or service providers. Examples of alerts include but are not limited to: a. A fraud or active duty alert that is included with a consumer report; b. A notice of credit freeze in response to a request for a consumer report; c. A notice of address discrepancy provided by a consumer reporting agency; d. Indications of a pattern of activity in a consumer report that is inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an applicant or customer such as: (i) A recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries; (ii) An unusual number of recently established credit relationships; (iii) A material change in the use of credit, especially with respect to recently established credit relationships; or (iv) An account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse of account privileges by a financial institution or creditor. (2) Suspicious documents. Examples of suspicious documents include: a. Documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or forged; b. Identification on which the photograph or physical description is inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer; c. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with information provided by the applicant or customer; d. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with readily accessible information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor, such as a signature card or a recent check; or e. An application that appears to have been altered or forged, or appears to have been destroyed and reassembled. (3) Suspicious personal identification, such as suspicious address change. Examples of suspicious identifying information include: a. Personal identifying information that is inconsistent with external information sources used by the financial institution or creditor. For example: (i) The address does not match any address in the consumer report; or (ii) The social security number (SSN) has not been issued, or is listed on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File. b. Personal identifying information provided by the customer is not consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the customer, such as a lack of correlation between the SSN range and date of birth. c. Personal identifying information or a phone number or address is associated with known fraudulent applications or activities as indicated by internal or third-party sources used by the financial institution or creditor. d. Other information provided, such as fictitious mailing address, mail drop addresses, jail addresses, invalid phone numbers, pager numbers or answering services, is associated with fraudulent activity. e. The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other applicants or customers. f. The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar to the account number or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of applicants or customers. g. The applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in response to notification that the application is incomplete. h. Personal identifying information is not consistent with personal identifying information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor. i. The applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer report. (4) Unusual use of or suspicious activity relating to a covered account. Examples of suspicious activity include: a. Shortly following the notice of a change of address for an account, city receives a request for the addition of authorized users on the account. b. A new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly associated with known patterns of fraud patterns. For example: (i) The customer fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent payments. c. An account is used in a manner that is not consistent with established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example: (i) Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments; (ii) A material change in purchasing or spending patterns. d. An account that has been inactive for a long period of time is used (taking into consideration the type of account, the expected pattern of usage and other relevant factors). e. Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the customer's account. f. The city is notified that the customer is not receiving paper account statements. g. The city is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in connection with a customer's account. h. The city is notified by a customer, law enforcement or another person that it has opened a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft. (5) Notice from customers, law enforcement, victims or other reliable sources regarding possible identity theft or phishing relating to covered accounts (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-249. - Prevention and mitigation of identity theft. (a) In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the utility manager. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the utility manager, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the utility manager, in his or her discretion, determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the utility manager: (1) Contact the customer; (2) Make the following changes to the account if, after contacting the customer, it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's covered account: a. Change any account numbers, passwords, security codes, or other security devices that permit access to an account; or b. Close the account; c. Cease attempts to collect additional charges from the customer and decline to sell the customer's account to a debt collector in the event that the customer's account has been accessed without authorization and such access has caused additional charges to accrue; d. Notify law enforcement, in the event that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's account causing additional charges to accrue or accessing personal identifying information; or e. Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (b) In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect an application for a new account, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the utility manager. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the utility manager, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the utility manager in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the utility manager: (1) Request additional identifying information from the applicant; (2) Deny the application for the new account; (3) Notify law enforcement of possible identity theft; or (4) Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-250. - Updating the program. The city council shall annually review and, as deemed necessary by the council, update the identity theft prevention program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the city and its covered accounts from identity theft. In so doing, the city council shall consider the following factors and exercise its discretion in amending the program: (1) The city's experiences with identity theft; (2) Updates in methods of identity theft; (3) Updates in customary methods used to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft; (4) Updates in the types of accounts that the city offers or maintains; and (5) Updates in service provider arrangements. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-251. - Program administration. Senior level staff is responsible for oversight of the program and for program implementation. The utility manager is responsible for reviewing reports prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with recommending material changes to the program, as necessary in the opinion of the utility manager to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or discontinued types of covered accounts. Any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to the mayor for consideration by the city council. (1) The utility manager will report to the mayor at least annually, on compliance with the red flag requirements. The report will address material matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as: a. The effectiveness of the policies and procedures of city in addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with the opening of covered accounts and with respect to existing covered accounts; b. Service provider arrangements; c. Significant incidents involving identity theft and management's response; and d. Recommendations for material changes to the program. (2) The utility manager is responsible for providing training to all employees responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account with respect to the implementation and requirements of the identity theft prevention program. The utility manager shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the amount and substance of training necessary. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-252. - Outside service providers. In the event that the city engages a service provider to perform an activity in connection with one or more covered accounts, the utility manager shall exercise his or her discretion in reviewing such arrangements in order to ensure, to the best of his or her ability, that the service provider's activities are conducted in accordance with policies and procedures, agreed upon by contract, that are designed to detect any red flags that may arise in the performance of the service provider's activities and take appropriate steps to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 1, 10-21-2008) Secs. 66-253—66-260. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - TREATMENT OF ADDRESS DISCREPANCIES[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 2, adopted October 21, 2008, enacted provisions which were not specifically amendatory of the Code and have been included herein as a new art. V, §§ 66-261—66-266, at the editors' discretion.
Sec. 66-261. - Short title. This article shall be known as the treatment of address discrepancies article. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 2, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-262. - Purpose. Pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.1, the purpose of this article is to establish a process by which the city will be able to form a reasonable belief that a consumer report relates to the consumer about whom it has requested a consumer credit report when the city has received a notice of address discrepancy. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 2, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-263. - Definitions. For purposes of this article, the following definitions apply: City means City of Jackson. Notice of address discrepancy means a notice sent to a user by a consumer reporting agency pursuant to 15 U.S.C. § 168 1(c)(h)(1), that informs the user of a substantial difference between the address for the consumer that the user provided to request the consumer report and the address(es) in the agency's file for the consumer. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 2, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-264. - Policy. In the event that the city receives a notice of address discrepancy, the city employee responsible for verifying consumer addresses for the purpose of providing the municipal service or account sought by the consumer shall perform one or more of the following activities, as determined to be appropriate by such employee: (1) Compare the information in the consumer report with: a. Information the city obtains and uses to verify a consumer's identity in accordance with the requirements of the Customer Information Program rules implementing 31 U.S.C. § 53 18(l); b. Information the city maintains in its own records, such as applications for service, change of address notices, other customer account records or tax records; c. Information the city obtains from third-party sources that are deemed reliable by the relevant city employee; or (2) Verify the information in the consumer report with the consumer. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 2, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-265. - Furnishing consumer's address to consumer reporting agency. (a) In the event that the city reasonably confirms that an address provided by a consumer to the city is accurate, the city is required to provide such address to the consumer reporting agency from which the city received a notice of address discrepancy with respect to such consumer. This information is required to be provided to the consumer reporting agency when: (1) The city is able to form a reasonable belief that the consumer report relates to the consumer about whom the city requested the report; (2) The city establishes a continuing relation with the consumer; and (3) The city regularly and in the ordinary course of business provides information to the consumer reporting agency from which it received the notice of address discrepancy. (b) Such information shall be provided to the consumer reporting agency as part of the information regularly provided by the city to such agency for the reporting period in which the city establishes a relationship with the customer. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 2, 10-21-2008) Sec. 66-266. - Methods of confirming consumer addresses. The city employee charged with confirming consumer addresses may, in his or her discretion, confirm the accuracy of an address through one or more of the following methods: (1) Verifying the address with the consumer; (2) Reviewing the city's records to verify the consumer's address; (3) Verifying the address through third party sources; or (4) Using other reasonable processes. (Ord. No. 01-10-2008, § 2, 10-21-2008)

div.head: Chapter 70 - VEGETATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; cemeteries, ch. 26; environment, ch. 34; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 50; subdivisions, ch. 54.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 70-1—70-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TREE PROTECTION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— An ordinance adopted April 6, 1999, amended §§ 70-21—70-38 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table.
Sec. 70-21. - Intent and purpose. Whereas trees provide buffers and screens against noise and air pollution; whereas human and animal life depend upon the capacity of trees to absorb carbon dioxide and supply oxygen in our atmosphere; whereas trees filter out pollutants from the air; whereas trees provide a haven for birds which in turn assist in the control of insects; whereas trees are physiologically, sociologically and aesthetically necessary counterpoints to the manmade urban setting; whereas trees tend to conserve and increase property values; whereas it is the policy of the city to conserve, develop and utilize its natural resources; whereas it is the policy of the city to protect its atmosphere, lands and waters from pollution, impairment, or destruction for the benefit, enjoyment and general welfare of its people; it is, therefore, the purpose of this article to regulate the removal of trees from the public property within the city in order to preserve, protect and enhance a most valuable natural resource entrusted to the commonwealth and to protect the health, safety and welfare of its citizens. It is the purpose and intent of this article to establish standards limiting the removal of and insuring the replacement of trees sufficient to safeguard the ecological and aesthetic environment necessary to a healthy and happy community. (Ord. No. 96-36, § I, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-22. - Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. Administrative officer means the city agent or employee specifically designated by the city council as an officer responsible for implementation and maintenance of a tree preservation program. City and City of Jackson, Georgia, means that area within the corporate boundaries of the City of Jackson, Georgia. Mayor and city council means the mayor and city council members of the City of Jackson. Park trees means trees and all other woody vegetation in city parks having individual names and all other areas owned by the city or to which the public has free access as a park provided by the city. Street trees mean trees and all other woody vegetation on land lying adjacent to right-of-way lines on either side of all city streets, state routes, avenues or ways within the city. Tree board or board means citizens and residents of the city who shall be appointed by the mayor and city council to exercise appellate review for the purpose of implementation and maintenance of a tree preservation program. Tree worthy of preservation means any tree which can reasonably be determined by the tree board to have lived no more than one-half of its normal life, or which is unique by reason of size, age, or some other outstanding quality, such as uniqueness, rarity or status as landmark or species specimen. (Ord. No. 96-36, § II, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-23. - Public tree care and planting. The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the right-of-way lines of all streets, to insure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The administrative officer or the mayor and city council may remove or cause or order to be removed any street or park tree which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with sections 70-29 through 70-34 of this article. Only the city and those acting under its authority shall plant trees in the public right-of-way. (Ord. No. 96-36, § III, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-24. - Tree topping. It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this article at the determination of the administrative officer or the mayor and city council. Cutting, killing or otherwise destroying trees by public service companies (other than the city) and natural gas companies performing normal construction and maintenance pursuant to applicable state or federal safety or construction laws and regulations is acceptable, provided, however, that the administrative officer shall review the procedures employed by such companies at least annually to determine whether they meet the purpose of this article, and shall recommend to the mayor and city council such additional ordinances as the administrative officer deems necessary to bring the procedures of such companies into compliance with the purpose of this article. (Ord. No. 96-36, § IV, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-25. - Pruning, corner clearance. Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light of any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased, or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs, which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any portion of a tree or shrub that overhangs onto public right-of-way when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign, or with pedestrian access on public walks or any public utility. (Ord. No. 96-36, § V, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-26. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. The mayor and city council, or the administrative officer, shall have the power to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life or property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The mayor and city council or administrative officer shall notify in writing the owners or persons in possession of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners or persons in possession at their own expense within 60 days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of the owners or persons in possession to comply with such a notice, the city shall be authorized to remove such trees and charge the costs of removal to the property owners or persons in possession. Failure to comply with an order to correct hazardous tree situations may also result in a citation pursuant to section 70-37, requiring the owners or persons in possession to appear before the municipal court. Nothing contained herein shall prevent the owners or persons in possession from negotiating with the city to allow the city access onto private property for the purposes of correction and/or removal, provided the owner or person in possession shall remain liable for the actual expenses of removal and disposal. (Ord. No. 96-36, § VI, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-27. - Arborist's license and bond. It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating or removing street or park trees within the city without first applying for and procuring a license. No license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. No license shall be issued to anyone to work on public trees in the right-of-way unless they are licensed contractors with minimal general liability insurance in the amount of $100,000.00 combined single limit. (Ord. No. 96-36, § VII, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-28. - Approval of site plans. Any commercial building permit application concerning property located within the city must be submitted to the administrative officer. The application must be accompanied by a site plan, which shall exhibit all existing trees on the public right-of-way. The plan shall indicate whether public trees are to remain or be removed. The administrative officer shall be responsible for implementation and maintenance of the tree preservation provisions of all site plans and accompanying information and exhibits immediately upon receipt of same. Applicant shall make every effort to avoid damaging public trees and provide site plans designed accordingly. All commercial site plans shall include a landscape easement, immediately adjacent to the right-of-way, which is a minimum of eight feet in width, for the purpose of tree planting, and exhibit tree planting based on the following schedule: Frontage less than 50 feet in length, one tree required. Frontage more than 50 feet in length, one tree per 50 feet plus one tree for any lineal footage over a multiple of 50 feet (example: 105 feet of frontage would require three trees). Existing trees may count towards the above schedule. If replacement trees are required by the administrative officer or the tree board, they shall equal or exceed the number of existing trees removed. Replacement trees shall be the minimum caliber nursery stock, as exhibited in the schedule below, balled and burlap or containerized. Owner/developer shall guarantee the survival and healthy condition of all replacement trees for two years from date of planting. The first three trees required of any site plan shall be shade trees from the large tree list below. Any other trees required above the quantity of three may be selected from the small or medium tree list. (Ord. No. 96-36, § VIII, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) _____ Sec. 70-29. - New or replacement tree approval.
All trees shall conform to standards of the American Nursery and Landscape Association. (Ord. No. 96-36, § IX, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) _____ Sec. 70-30. - Spacing and minimum size planting areas. The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 70-29 of this article, and no tree may be planted closer together than the following: small trees, 15 feet; medium trees, 20 feet; and large trees, 40 feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. The minimum planting area for small trees shall be four feet by eight feet, for medium trees six feet by eight feet, and large trees eight feet by eight feet. (Ord. No. 96-36, § X, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-31. - Distance from the curb and sidewalk. The distance street trees may be planted from the curbs or curb lines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 70-29 of this article and no tree may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: small trees, two feet; medium trees, three feet; and large trees, four feet. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XI, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-32. - Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet to any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curb lines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any fire hydrant. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XII, 11-18-1996) Sec. 70-33. - Utilities. No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 70-29 of this article may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, or other utility. No trees may be planted within 30 feet of transmission lines. In the interest of establishing shade/canopy (large type) trees, the administrative officer or the tree board shall have the discretion to allow large or small trees to be placed outside of the required tree planting zones, if utility lines and/or other site conditions do not allow for the establishment of proper tree planting areas. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XIII, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-34. - Tree protection during development. During any building, renovating or razing operations, the builder shall erect and maintain suitable protective barriers around all trees specified to be maintained so as to prevent damage to said trees and shall not allow storage of equipment, materials, debris or fill to be placed in this area except as may be necessary for a reasonable time if no other storage or staging is available. All public trees unless specifically exempted by the administrative officer shall be protected from construction activity. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XIV, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-35. - Interference with city tree preservation/conservation. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city, or any of its agents, while engaging in or about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private or public grounds, as authorized in this article. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XV, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-36. - Decisions of and review by administrative officer and appeal to tree board. The administrative officer shall carefully review all site plans and make decisions based upon this article and any other ordinance provision of the city or state or federal law or regulation. Any party who disagrees with a decision made by the administrative officer shall have a right to review before the tree board. The following rules for hearings and decisions shall apply: (1) When deciding whether or not to approve a commercial site plan, the administrative officer shall consider only site plans which have been submitted to the planning and zoning office. If the administrative officer reaches any decision other than approval, he must notify the applicant in writing that the applicant's site plan for trees has been disapproved by the administrative officer and the specific reasons for the unfavorable decision. The applicant will be notified that he is entitled to a hearing before the administrative officer upon request. (2) An applicant's request for a review hearing before the administrative officer must be in writing and must be delivered to the planning and zoning office within seven days of the date that the administrative officer mailed to the applicant a notice of an unfavorable decision. Upon the filing of such a request for hearing, the administrative officer shall conduct a hearing within seven days of the filing of the request. At the hearing, the administrative officer shall conduct the proceedings. The applicant will be entitled to appear and present relevant evidence. The administrative officer may also hear from any interested parties and consider any relevant facts, provided the applicant has an ample opportunity to examine same. The applicant shall be entitled to be represented by counsel. The administrative officer shall not have subpoena power. Minutes of the meeting, including a tape recording, shall be made by the administrative officer. (3) At the hearing, the administrative officer may ask questions of the applicant and may attempt to resolve the issue(s) leading to the unfavorable decision by stipulation. After the hearing has been concluded the administrative officer will issue a decision in writing within 48 hours and deliver a copy to the applicant by regular mail. The decision will state specific reasons for any ruling other than approval of the tree site plan. The administrative officer may issue an approval of a site plan as amended by stipulation of the applicant, he may approve the plan as originally filed, or he may disapprove and state its specific reasons. (4) An applicant may appeal any unfavorable ruling to the tree board, which shall conduct a de novo hearing. The applicant's rights will remain the same as in paragraph (2) above. An appeal to the tree board shall be in writing, and it shall include a copy of the administrative officer's decision and shall state specifically those portions of the administrative officer's decision with which the applicant disagrees. The appeal must be filed with the administrative officer within 30 days of the date of the administrative officer's decision. The tree board shall hear the appeal at the next regular tree board meeting after the appeal is filed. The decision of the tree board shall be issued in writing within 48 hours after the hearing and a copy shall be mailed to the applicant. Any decision that does not approve the site plan shall state specific reasons for the decision. (5) The following rules of procedure shall apply in those cases where the mayor and city council or administrative officer exercises the power to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property, pursuant to the authority of section 70-26: a. When it is determined that a tree or trees constitute a hazard to life or property or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city, the mayor and city council or administrative officer shall issue a written notice to the owners and persons in possession of the property stating the location of the tree or trees and the reason that removal is required. Such notice shall be in writing and shall notify the owners and persons in possession that they are to perform all removal and dispose of all debris within 60 days of the receipt of such notice. The notice will also state that any interested party has the right to demand a hearing before the tree board within seven days after service of the notice. A notice shall be considered served upon the owners or persons in possession when actually received by such interested party either by personal delivery or certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed and properly posted to the last known mailing address of the owner or person in possession. If such interested person cannot be found after diligent search or attempted delivery of the notice by certified mail is returned undelivered for any reason, notice shall be considered delivered when advertised in the official organ in the county for two consecutive weeks and a copy of the notice is conspicuously posted upon the premises which are the subject matter of the notice. The date of delivery in such cases shall be the later of the date of posting or the date of the publication of the last of the two advertisements. b. If any owner or person in possession of the premises notifies the mayor and city council or administrative officer in writing of an objection to the planned action, a hearing will be scheduled before any action is taken upon the property in question. The hearing shall be conducted before the tree board, and the decision of the tree board can be appealed to the city council. Notice of the hearing, conduct of the hearing and notice of the decision will generally follow the same procedures as in cases of disapproval of site plans. c. A decision of the tree board shall be appealable to the city council by the filing of a written notice of appeal in the office of the city clerk within seven days of the date of the written decision of the tree board. The initial 60-day period in which to comply with the order of the mayor and city council or administrative officer shall be tolled during the hearing and appeal process. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XVI, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-37. - Penalty. Any violation of this article shall be punishable by the issuance of a written citation either by the administrative officer or the city police department. Failure to comply with an order issued by the administrative officer, the tree board, or the mayor and city council, pursuant to this article shall be a violation of this article subject to issuance of citation. Any citation issued under this article shall be tried before the municipal court of the city. Any person convicted of a violation shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00 for each violation; each tree maintained or destroyed in violation of this article shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XVII, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999) Sec. 70-38. - Appointment of members of tree board. (a) Qualifications. All members of the tree board must be residents of the city. (b) Officers. The membership of the board shall elect by majority vote a chairperson, a vice-chairperson, and a secretary. The chairperson shall preside, the vice-chairperson shall preside in the absence of the chairperson, and the secretary shall be responsible for keeping records of the actions of the board and preparing and delivering decisions. (c) Meetings and voting. All voting on decisions shall be by roll call vote and the results of the voting shall be kept by the secretary in the minutes. All votes shall be by majority vote, and the member acting as chairperson shall be allowed to vote. There must be a majority quorum present and voting in order to conduct any business. Members shall adhere to the same rules as to disqualifications and conflicts of interest as the city council. The chairperson shall set meeting times and places, so long as the meeting place is within the city. The board shall establish the time of its meetings by the giving of at least 48 hours' notice to members and all interested parties and it shall comply with the state's open meetings law (O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq.). (d) Appointments. Members shall be appointed by the mayor and the city council. They shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council. The members shall be appointed for three-year staggered terms. The board shall be comprised of three members. They shall serve without compensation, but may apply to the city council for reimbursement for any actual expenses incurred in their service, with the approval of the chairperson of the tree board. (Ord. No. 96-36, § XVIII, 11-18-1996; Ord. of 4-6-1999)

div.head: Chapter 74 - ZONING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Because the Jackson Zoning Ordinance is undergoing frequent revision, the city has chosen to withhold it from being printed in the Code for the near future. The updated ordinance is available from city hall. Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; location of adult entertainment establishments, § 8-33; businesses, ch. 18; floods, ch. 38; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 50; subdivisions, ch. 54. State Law reference— Conflict of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; The Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local government exercise of zoning powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2; effect of zoning laws on covenants running with the land, O.C.G.A. § 44-5-60; authority to adopt plans and exercise the power of zoning, Ga. Sec. 74-1. - Public hearings. The city council is authorized to hold all public hearings in connection with amendments to the city zoning ordinance and the maps thereof. (Res. of 4-2-1973; Amend. of 3-17-1998; Ord. No. 1-12-2007, § 1, 12-27-2007) Sec. 74-2. - Provisions saved from repeal. The city's zoning rules and regulations, as amended, adopted December 16, 1985, are not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect. The city adopted a revision of the Jackson Zoning Ordinance on December 27, 2007, effective January 1, 2008. A copy of the City of Jackson Zoning Ordinance may be obtained from city hall.
